## Functional Description of Turso Sync Announcement Page

**1. Page Overview:**
This is an announcement or blog post page detailing the launch and features of "Turso Sync," a new capability for Turso databases. Its primary purpose is to inform users about syncing local SQLite databases with Turso Cloud, explaining its usage, technical aspects, and future roadmap.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Global Announcement Banner:**
    *   Content: A text announcement stating "The next evolution of SQLite is here!" followed by a link to "Read Announcement".
*   **Global Navigation Area:**
    *   Content: A brand logo (Turso) linked to the homepage.
    *   Navigation links: "Docs", "Cloud Pricing", "Blog", "Changelog".
    *   Service links: A link to "Login" and a call-to-action button labeled "Get Started".
    *   Social/External links: Icons linking to GitHub, Discord, and a generic external link.
*   **Article Header Section:**
    *   Content:
        *   Publication date: "Oct 8, 2023".
        *   Article title: "Introducing Databases Anywhere with Turso Sync".
        *   Author information: An author name "Nikita Sivukhin" with an associated profile image.
        *   A prominent graphic featuring "TURSO SYNC" text and the Turso logo.
*   **Article Content Area:** This is the main body of the blog post, structured with headings and explanatory text.
    *   **Introduction:** Explanatory text introducing Turso Sync as a solution for modern applications requiring offline capabilities and seamless experiences, enabling local SQLite databases to sync with Turso Cloud.
    *   **Usage Section:**
        *   Heading: "Usage".
        *   Text: Details about the `@tursodatabase/sync` package, its `connect` method requiring a remote database URL and authentication token, and `push`/`pull` methods for interaction.
        *   Informational Note: A dedicated area providing information for browser usage, mentioning the `@tursodatabase/sync-wasm` package and a link to a blog post for more details.
        *   Text: Instructions for updating applications using `@tursodatabase/database` to use `pull` / `push` loops for remote syncing.
        *   Code Example: A multi-part code block demonstrating JavaScript code for connecting to a database, implementing `checkpoint`, `pull`, and `push` functions using `async`/`await` patterns, and background execution.
    *   **Authentication Section:**
        *   Heading: "Authentication".
        *   Text: Explanation of advanced authentication capabilities for offline applications with local sync.
        *   Feature List (Numbered):
            1.  **Fine-grained token permissions:** Describes the ability to limit access per table and per operation (e.g., `data_read`, `data_add`, `schema_add`). Includes a command-line interface (CLI) example `turso db tokens create <db> -p all:data_read -p table:data_update`.
            2.  **External Auth provider support:** Details adding external JWKS URLs and using provider-issued tokens. Includes CLI examples `turso org jwks ...` and `turso org jwks template --database <db> -p all:data_read,data_add`.
        *   Informational Note: A dedicated area stating that during Turso Beta, only Clerk and Auth0 are supported OIDC providers.
        *   Text: A link to "documentation" for more authentication features.
    *   **Conflict Resolution Section:**
        *   Heading: "Conflict resolution".
        *   Text: Describes the default row-level logical logging using a Last-Push-Wins conflict resolution strategy.
        *   Diagram: An illustrative diagram showing a "remote" database and "client #1" and "client #2" databases, with arrows indicating `push` operations at different times (`t1` through `t4`) and how the last push wins for a specific `row1`.
        *   Text: Explanation of a custom `transform` hook for more sophisticated conflict resolution.
        *   Code Example: A JavaScript code block demonstrating a `connect` method call that includes a `transform` function for custom mutation operations (e.g., updating a counter).
    *   **Technical Details Section:**
        *   Heading: "Technical details".
        *   Diagram: A comprehensive diagram illustrating the `remote` database, `client` database, `DB file`, and `DB WAL` components. It shows "physical pull" of WAL frames and "logical push" of CDC changes, with data items and metadata represented.
        *   Text: Explains that the sync package maintains a `tursodatabase` instance with standard components (database file, WAL) and additional metadata files.
        *   Text: Describes the hybrid synchronization approach.
        *   Numbered List:
            1.  **Local changes are pushed:** As logical mutations for flexible conflict resolution.
            2.  **Remote changes are pulled:** As physical pages, making the local replica byte-for-byte identical to the remote.
        *   Informational Note: A dedicated area stating the remote database acts as the source of truth, motivating physical updates for pull operations, and noting that fully distributed, peer-to-peer synchronization is not supported.
        *   Text: Explains WAL retention and rebasing after a pull operation, and the `db.checkpoint()` method for optimizing the WAL.
    *   **What's Coming Next? Section:**
        *   Heading: "What's Coming Next?".
        *   Text: Expresses excitement for the Beta launch and opportunities for optimizations and architectural shifts.
        *   Feature List:
            *   Front-end applications can implement offline-first behavior.
            *   Machine learning pipelines can use `@tursodatabase/sync` for training and synchronization.
            *   Backend applications can achieve low-latency read/write operations.
        *   Roadmap List:
            *   Partial sync.
            *   CDC optimizations.
            *   Broader language support (Go, Python, JavaScript).
            *   Mobile ecosystem integration.
*   **Call-to-Action Section:**
    *   Content: A prominent call-to-action button labeled "TRY TURSO IN THE BROWSER".
*   **Article Sharing Area:**
    *   Content: A collection of buttons for sharing the article: "Share article" text followed by buttons for Twitter/X, Email, and Copy Link.
*   **Footer Section:**
    *   **Copyright Information:** Text stating "© Turso 2023" and the Turso logo.
    *   **Navigation Lists (Categorized):**
        *   **Turso Cloud:** "Quickstart", "Documentation", "Pricing", "API Status", "Terms of Use", "Privacy Policy".
        *   **Turso Database:** "Embeded Replicas", "Database Branching", "Backups & Recovery", "Platform API", "Changelog", "Releases".
        *   **Company:** "About", "Contact Us", "Support", "Trust", "Blog".
    *   **Social Media Links:** Icons linking to RSS feed, Discord, GitHub, Twitter/X, and LinkedIn.

**3. Interactive Elements:**

*   **Links:** "Read Announcement" (in banner), "Docs", "Cloud Pricing", "Blog", "Changelog" (in global navigation), GitHub icon, Discord icon, generic external link icon (in global navigation), "Login" (button), "blog post" (within Usage section), "documentation" (within Authentication section), all items in the Footer navigation lists, and social media icons in the Footer.
*   **Buttons:** "Get Started" (global navigation), "TRY TURSO IN THE BROWSER" (main content call-to-action), "Share article" buttons (Twitter/X, Email, Copy Link).
*   **Command-line Interface (CLI) Examples:** Text snippets representing commands users can execute in a terminal for managing Turso (e.g., `turso db tokens create`, `turso org jwks`).
*   **Code Examples:** Blocks of programming code demonstrating how to interact with Turso Sync programmatically.

**4. Content Details:**

*   **Headings:** "Usage", "Authentication", "Conflict resolution", "Technical details", "What's Coming Next?".
*   **Key Concepts:** Turso Sync, SQLite, Turso Cloud, `@tursodatabase/sync`, `push`, `pull`, `checkpoint`, `connect`, authentication tokens, fine-grained permissions, external Auth providers, JWKS, OIDC, Clerk, Auth0, Last-Push-Wins, `transform` hook, logical mutations, physical pages, WAL, CDC optimizations, partial sync.
*   **Code Snippets:** JavaScript examples for database connection, checkpointing, pulling, pushing, and custom transform logic.
*   **Diagrams:** Visual representations of database synchronization flow, client/remote interactions, and internal components of the sync package.
*   **Roadmap Items:** Partial sync, CDC optimizations, broader language support (Go, Python, JavaScript), mobile ecosystem integration.

### 1. Page Overview

This page is a blog post or announcement detailing a new feature named "Live Materialized Views" for the Turso database product. Its primary purpose is to inform users about the feature, explain its technical aspects, and encourage engagement with the product.

### 2. Sections

**A. Global Announcement Banner**
*   A promotional text "The next evolution of SQLite is here!"
*   A link labeled "Read Announcement" which navigates to related information.

**B. Header Section**
*   **Site Identity:** A Turso logo link.
*   **Primary Navigation:** A set of links: "Docs", "Cloud Pricing", "Blog", "Changelog".
*   **Utility Navigation:**
    *   A link represented by a GitHub icon, likely leading to the Turso GitHub repository.
    *   A link represented by a Discord icon, likely leading to the Turso Discord community.
    *   A "Login" link for user authentication.
    *   A "Get Started" button, serving as a primary call-to-action for new users.

**C. Article Content Section**
*   **Article Metadata:**
    *   Publication date: "Oct 9, 2025".
    *   Article Title: "Introducing Real-Time Data with Materialized Views in Turso".
    *   Author Information: An author profile image and the author's name "Glauber Costa".
*   **Feature Visual:** A prominent graphic containing the text "LIVE VIEWS" and the Turso logo, acting as a visual identifier for the feature.
*   **Introduction:** Explanatory text introducing Materialized Views, Live Data, and the new Live Materialized Views feature in Turso.
*   **Section: How Materialized Views usually work.**
    *   Heading: "How Materialized Views usually work."
    *   Detailed text explaining the function and common limitations of traditional Materialized Views.
    *   A numbered list describing two typical drawbacks:
        1.  Performance cost of recomputing views affecting write speeds.
        2.  Views becoming stale and requiring periodic recomputation.
    *   Text explaining how Turso's Live Materialized Views address these issues through Incremental View Maintenance (IVM) and the DBSP framework.
    *   Text about integration with streaming systems like Kafka.
*   **Section: Incremental Computation**
    *   Heading: "Incremental Computation"
    *   Text defining incremental computation and its efficiency, highlighting that computation time scales with the size of data changes, not the entire dataset.
    *   Explanation of DBSP (Differential Datalog) as a framework that compiles complex query languages into a dataflow circuit using operators (e.g., filter, project, aggregate) to process changes (deltas).
    *   An example SQL query: `SELECT role, count(*), avg(salary) FROM employees WHERE company_id = 123 GROUP BY role;`
    *   A functional diagram illustrating the data flow for the example query, showing components like "Delta Input", "Filter", "Aggregate", "Project", and "Delta Output".
*   **Section: Transactional Guarantees**
    *   Heading: "Transactional Guarantees"
    *   Text explaining that Turso provides transactional guarantees for Materialized Views, ensuring the same isolation level as the rest of the database.
    *   A code example demonstrating a transaction:
        *   `BEGIN;` statement.
        *   `SELECT * FROM v;` (with tabular output showing 'role', 'count(*)', 'avg(salary)' data).
        *   `INSERT INTO employees` statement.
        *   `SELECT * FROM v;` (with tabular output showing the updated data after insert).
        *   `ROLLBACK;` statement.
        *   `SELECT * FROM v;` (with tabular output showing the data reverted after rollback).
*   **Section: The state of Live Materialized Views on Turso**
    *   Heading: "The state of Live Materialized Views on Turso"
    *   Text introducing the operators implemented by Turso based on DBSP.
    *   A list of currently implemented operators:
        *   "Join" (for SQL Join operations).
        *   "Filter" (for `WHERE` clauses).
        *   "Aggregate" (for `SUM`, `COUNT`, `AVG`, `MIN`, `MAX` functions, with more planned).
        *   "Merge" (for `UNION` and `UNION ALL` operations).
    *   Text indicating the status of other operators (delay operator) and features (recursive CTEs) as not yet implemented.
    *   A disclaimer regarding the stability of the on-disk format and production readiness, including a link to a "Turso bug challenge".
*   **Call-to-Action:** A button labeled "TRY TURSO IN THE BROWSER", prompting users to try the product immediately.
*   **Article Sharing Options:**
    *   Text: "Share article"
    *   A set of links for sharing the article via email, Twitter/X, LinkedIn, and a general copy-link function.

They also protect you from committing ancient credentials (such as API keys or database connection strings) to your application source."

   *   Page Title: "Login methods"
   *   Introductory Text: "We offer multiple ways to log in and options to restrict login methods for added security. Login restrictions are available to workspaces on our Business and Enterprise plans. SAML authentication and IP restrictions are only available to workspaces on our Enterprise plan."
   *   Overview Text: "Linear provides several options for members to log into a workspace and allows for different tiers of restriction methods for added security."
   *   Google Authentication Text: "Members can authenticate with Linear using Google authentication when using a Google supported email address."
   *   Email Login Text: "When selecting Continue with Email as the login option, an email will be sent to your inbox containing a login link. You can either use the link to log in or copy the code provided in the email and paste it into the "Enter code" field on the login page."
   * Recommendation Text: "We recommend whitelisting notifications@linear.app and/or pm_bounces@pm-bounces.linear.app as trusted senders in your email settings to ensure login emails reach your inbox."
   *   Passkey Text: "Passkeys allow a secure and fast login without having to rely on passwords. They are supported by all major browsers, mobile operating systems, and many password managers like 1Password. You can register multiple devices to log in via passkey from Preferences > Account > Security & Access."
   *   SAML Text: "Refer to our SAML help docs."
   *   Restrict Login Methods Text: "Admins can require specific login methods to allow for all members. This setting can be managed by navigating to Settings > Administration > Security. Admins can login through any method to ensure they have access to these settings and prevent lockouts for other users."
   *   Restrict Login IPs Text: "IP restrictions are available only on the Enterprise plan. Additionally, logins can be restricted to specific IPs to enable an extra security layer for accessing Linear. Once set, all direct user access to Linear, including web, desktop, mobile, and API access, will be limited to the set of configured IPs. Please contact support@linear.app if you're an Admin on an Enterprise plan and would like to block an IP range."
   *   Switch Accounts and Workspaces Text: "You can log in to multiple user accounts in Linear, which allows you to switch between workspaces associated with those accounts without re-authenticating. To add a user account:" followed by numbered steps.

    *   **On-page Navigation (Table of Contents):**
        *   A list of links to major sections within the current document: "Data included in the import," "What import method should I choose?," and "Considerations before importing."
    *   **Data Included in the Import Section:**
        *   Heading: "Data included in the import."
        *   Introductory text explaining that data is imported from Jira based on specified field mappings.
        *   A table with two main data points for each entry: "Jira" field name and its corresponding "Linear" field name. Examples include "Summary" (Jira) maps to "Title" (Linear), "Description" (Jira) maps to "Converted into markdown and used as issue description" (Linear), "Assignee" (Jira) maps to "Assignee (best effort match)" (Linear), and many more.
        *   A note stating that data not included in the table, such as custom fields, will not import to Linear, and that API credentials are required for fetching files.
    *   **What Import Method Should I Choose? Section:**
        *   Heading: "What import method should I choose?"
        *   A table comparing two import types: "API imports" and "CSV imports." For each import type, there are sections for "Pros" and "Cons."
            *   **API imports:** Pros include retaining most data, supporting Jira Sync functionality. Cons include requiring Admin permissions in the source Jira project.
            *   **CSV imports:** Pros include not requiring high permissions, enabling import of many Jira projects at once. Cons include not supporting Jira sync functionality.
        *   Additional text explaining that both API and CSV options will automatically label imported issues and make them deletable within 7 days.
        *   Information about using a CLI tool for importing, noting it doesn't import as much data and doesn't label imported issues.
    *   **Considerations Before Importing Section:**
        *   Heading: "Considerations before importing."
        *   Textual advice outlining functionalities that users should be aware of before importing, as they may impact import decisions.
    *   **Syncing Changes Back to Jira Section:**
        *   Heading: "Syncing changes back to Jira."
        *   Introductory text explaining the benefit of Jira sync for teams using both platforms.
        *   Two selectable tabs to view specific instructions: "API credential imports" and "CSV imports."
            *   Under "API credential imports" (selected state): Instructions for configuring the Jira integration before import, matching Jira issue keys, and enabling issue sync.
        *   A link to "Jira documentation" for more information about Jira Sync.
    *   **Mapping Jira Users to Linear Section:**
        *   Heading: "Mapping Jira users to Linear."
        *   Textual explanation of how the importer attempts to match existing users and provides guidance on connecting Jira accounts to Linear in "integration settings" for best performance.

        *   An image showing the Turso logo combined with the BÆRSkin logo.
        *   Introductory text describing Kafka's role in building real-time applications and its drawbacks.

        *   A section titled "SQLite as the solution," explaining the architecture chosen by BÆRSkin Tactical Supply Co., and a quote from Gus Fune.
        *   A section titled "Conclusion," summarizing the benefits of SQLite-based solutions and mentioning cost savings achieved using Turso Cloud. Includes a call to action to start a journey with Turso Cloud.

Includes a copyright notice.

    *   **Author:** Glauber Costa
    *   **Date:** Aug 12, 2025
    *   **Quotes:**

**1. Page Overview:**
This is a blog post page discussing the integration of the Kin AI assistant with Turso's libSQL for on-device vector search. Its primary purpose is to inform readers about this technological advancement, its benefits for privacy and performance, and the underlying technical motivations.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Announcement Banner:**
    *   Contains informational text: "The next evolution of SQLite is here!"
    *   Includes a link labeled "Read Announcement" which leads to further details about the announcement.

    *   Brand logo and name "TURSO" (functions as a link to the homepage).
    *   A set of navigation links: "Docs", "Cloud Pricing", "Blog", "Changelog".
    *   A collection of utility links represented by icons: GitHub, X (formerly Twitter), Discord.
    *   User authentication links: "Login" and a "Get Started" call-to-action button.

*   **Article Content:**
    *   **Article Metadata:** Displays the publication date "Oct 21, 2024" and the author's name "Simon Wett Henricksen" with an associated author image.
    *   **Article Title:** "Local first AI assistant Kin leverages Turso's libSQL for on-device native Vector Search".
    *   **Hero Illustration:** An image depicting two stylized character representations, one labeled "TURSO" and the other "KIN", visually representing the subjects of the article.
    *   **Introduction:** Explains what Kin is (a personal AI), its role as a companion, coach, and mentor, and its always-available nature. Further elaborates on Kin's underlying technology, including NLP techniques for long-term memory and structured information extraction, and the importance of trust and data control for AI relationships.
    *   **Section: Local first for trust:**
        *   Discusses the design principle of building Kin as a local-first mobile app, leveraging on-device machine learning and AI chips.
        *   Emphasizes data privacy, stating user data resides on-device in Turso-powered SQLite databases, ensuring it cannot be hacked via cloud access.
        *   Describes the implementation of local vector search using Turso's open-source contribution fork of SQLite, libSQL, which supports native vector embeddings.
        *   Mentions the capability for on-device Retrieval Augmentation Generation (RAG).
        *   Highlights the benefit of a superior user experience due to reduced reliance on cloud servers and network latency.
    *   **Section: Why Turso?:**
        *   Explains the evaluation of various database options, including a graph engine, and the reasons for their unsuitability for production.
        *   Details challenges encountered with traditional SQLite for production use.
        *   Describes the discovery and suitability of libSQL by Turso, citing its support for vector embeddings, efficiency, and scalability comparable to SQLite.
        *   Emphasizes the advantage of a single on-device database for all functionalities, including vector search, and its benefits for fault tolerance and reduced network lag.
        *   **App Interface Screenshot:** An image showing a mobile phone screen displaying the Kin app's interface. This includes a chat message, historical data summaries ("new memories", "messages", "journal entries"), "Focus Areas" with items like "Making Progress" and "Stress Management", and "Reminders".
    *   **Section: The future:**

1. Page Overview:
Documentation page explaining Persistent Disks functionality within the Render platform. It describes how persistent disks work, their use cases, how to set them up, monitor their usage, and transfer files.

2. Sections:
   - Title: "Persistent Disks"
   - Introduction: Explains that persistent disks preserve filesystem changes across deploys and restarts and that they can be attached to a paid Render service (web service, private service, or background worker). Includes a notice stating that Render services have an ephemeral filesystem by default, meaning any changes made without a persistent disk are lost on redeploy or restart.
   - Use Cases: Lists examples of services for which persistent disks are useful (infrastructure components, blogging platforms, collaboration apps, custom datastores) and a note about Render-managed Postgres and Key Value instances.
   - Disk Properties: Mentions that persistent disks use the same high-performance SSDs as Render Postgres and Key Value Instances and that all disks are encrypted with automatic daily snapshots.
   - Setup: Explains the process of setting up a persistent disk, including a note to understand limitations and considerations. States that persistent disks can be created from the Render Dashboard during service creation or from the service's Disks page.
   - Disk Configuration: Shows a form to configure a disk with the following input fields: "Mount path" (with an example) and a set of selectable sizes (1 GB, 5 GB, 10 GB, 50 GB, 100 GB).
   - Setup Steps: Describes the steps involved in setting up the disk, including: setting the mount path, choosing a disk size, and clicking the "Add disk" button.
   - Monitoring Usage: States that you can view disk usage over time from the service's Disks page. Shows a graph of disk usage over time, with labels for disk usage amount and time.
   - Disk Snapshots: Explains that Render automatically creates a snapshot of the persistent disk once every 24 hours. Includes an "Important" notice with the following information: that restoring a snapshot results in data loss of any changes after the snapshot, that Render does not support partial snapshot restoration, and that snapshots used for custom databases should not be restored for database recovery purposes.
   - Snapshot Restoration: Explains that you can restore a snapshot from the service's Disks page. Shows a list of snapshots with dates and times, each with a "Restore" button.
   - Restoring a Custom Database: Explains that disk restores should not be used for database recovery if the persistent disk is used for backing a custom database instance. Suggests using database-specific tools like mysqldump or mongodump for backup and restoration.
   - Transferring Files: Introduces methods for securely transferring files between a disk-backed service and a local machine. Mentions SCP and Magic-Wormhole.
   - SCP: Explains how to transfer files using SCP after setting up SSH for the service. Includes example ssh and scp commands. Recommends using SCP with a specific flag for the SFTP protocol.
   - Magic-Wormhole: Explains how to transfer files using Magic-Wormhole library. States to visit the Shell page in Render Dashboard to use Magic-Wormhole. States to install Magic-Wormhole using the shell, if Docker is used. Includes an example wormhole command.
   - Disk Limitations and Considerations: Provides a list of considerations and limitations when attaching a persistent disk. This includes information on data preservation, access restrictions, scaling limitations, downtime during redeploys, and restrictions on adding disks to cron jobs.

3. Interactive Elements:
   - Link to Render Dashboard (multiple instances): Navigates to the Render Dashboard.
   - Button: "Add disk" - Adds a persistent disk with the configured settings.
   - Button: "Restore" (for each snapshot) - Restores the disk to the selected snapshot.
   - Selectable Disk Sizes: 1 GB, 5 GB, 10 GB, 50 GB, 100 GB - Chooses the size of the persistent disk.
   - Link to "Disks page": Navigates to the service's Disks page in the Render Dashboard.
   - Link to "Shell page": Navigates to the service's Shell page in the Render Dashboard.
   - Link to "See details": Provides additional information about database restore.

4. Content Details:
   - Heading: Persistent Disks
   - Body Text: Explanatory text about persistent disks, their use cases, limitations, and setup instructions.
   - Labels: Mount path, Size, Disk Usage, Across all instances
   - Example Mount Path: /var/data
   - Code snippets: Example ssh, scp, and wormhole commands.
   - Disclaimer Text: Information about ephemeral filesystems, data loss, and database restoration.
   - Notice text: "By default, Render services have an ephemeral filesystem."

*   Announcement Section: Message to Turso users linking to a detailed platform announcement.
*   Main Content: Discusses the background and reasons for the SQLite rewrite, including past efforts, challenges, and the decision to rewrite SQLite in Rust. It also highlights the benefits of the rewrite and community response. Includes several sub-headings such as "But something was missing", "Then something unexpected happened", "Then something extraordinary happened". Second list includes "Embedded Replicas" category with links to Embedded Replicas, Database Branching, Backups & Recovery, Platform API. Also, the Turso logo with "Turso 2026" text is shown. Social media icons are also present, linking to Turso's profiles on various platforms.

4. Content Details:
*   Title: We will rewrite SQLite. And we are going all-in
*   Date: Jan 21, 2025
*   Author: Glauber Costa
*   Announcement: The next evolution of SQLite is here! Read Announcement.
*   Body text describes the reasoning behind rewriting SQLite.
*   Subheadings: "But something was missing.", "Then something unexpected happened.", "Then something extraordinary happened."

1. Page Overview:
Documentation page explaining the Render Penetration Testing Policy. The purpose is to inform users about acceptable security testing practices on the Render platform.

2. Sections:
   *   Header: Contains the Render logo, navigation links (Docs, Changelog), a search input, a link to "Ask AI", a "Sign In" link, and a "Get Started" button.
   *   Sidebar Navigation: A categorized list of documentation topics, including "Integrations", "User Management", "Enterprise Organizations", "Platform Protections", "Compliance", and "Compare". Each category contains a list of links to specific documentation pages. The "Compliance" category is expanded and the "Pentest policy" item is selected.
   *   Main Content:
        *   Article Title: "Render Penetration Testing Policy"
        *   Subtitle: "Understand which types of pentests are allowed."
        *   Introduction: Explains that Render customers can perform security assessments on their own Render-hosted services without prior approval.
        *   Section: "Prohibited testing" - Details what types of testing are forbidden, including testing Render's core infrastructure or another user's infrastructure. Mentions Denial of Service (DoS) testing.
        *   Section: "Communicating with Render" - Explains the process for reporting security issues, linking to the Vulnerability Disclosure Program.
   *   Page Actions:
        *   "Copy page" dropdown.
        *   Table of Contents: Contains links to "Render Penetration Testing Policy", "Prohibited testing", and "Communicating with Render" within the current page.
        *   "Did this page help?" link.
   *   Footer: Contains links to "Pricing", "Blog", "Security", "Customers", and "Careers", and a copyright notice "Render 2025".

3. Interactive Elements:
   *   Search input: "Search the docs" - Allows users to search the documentation.
   *   "Ask AI" link - Navigates to an AI assistant for documentation.
   *   "Sign In" link - Navigates to the sign-in page.
   *   "Get Started" button - Navigates to the sign-up/onboarding page.
   *   Sidebar Navigation Links: Each item in the sidebar is a link to the corresponding documentation page.
   *   "Copy page" dropdown: Allows copying the page content.
   *   Table of Contents Links: Allows navigation to specific sections within the current page.
   *   "Did this page help?" link - Submits feedback about the page's usefulness.
   *   Footer Links: Links to different sections of the Render website (Pricing, Blog, Security, Customers, Careers).

4. Content Details:
   *   Article Title: Render Penetration Testing Policy
   *   Subtitle: Understand which types of pentests are allowed.
   *   Prohibited testing:
        *   Direct testing of Render's core infrastructure, APIs, or other services not provisioned for the individual customer's use is strictly forbidden without explicit consent from Render.
        *   Testing of another Render user's infrastructure is not permitted without explicit consent.
        *   Engaging in any form of Denial of Service (DoS) testing against Render infrastructure including customer environments is expressly prohibited. Render provides free DDoS protection to all hosted services, and violating this policy by attempting DoS attacks jeopardizes the security and availability of services across our platform.
   *   Communicating with Render:
        *   If you discover a security issue within the Render product, please submit a report to our Vulnerability Disclosure Program immediately.
        *   If Render detects abusive activities related to your security testing, we will reach out to you to stop your activities.

1. Page Overview:
Documentation page about High Availability (HA) for Render Postgres databases. The purpose is to explain how HA works, its prerequisites, setup process, failover behavior, and limitations.

2. Sections:
   *   Header: Contains the Render logo, links to Docs and Changelog, a search field, a link to "Ask AI", and "Sign In" and "Get Started" buttons.
   *   Sidebar Navigation: A list of links to different documentation sections, including "Workflows", "SDK reference", "Datastores", "Postgres databases", "Networking", and "Custom domains". Under "Postgres databases" it contains further links to "Overview", "Creating & connecting", "Recovery & backups", "Database credentials", "Read replicas", "High availability", "Admin apps", "Extensions", "Connection pooling", "Version upgrades", "Troubleshooting performance", "Flexible plans", and "Legacy instance types".
   *   Main Content:
        *   Heading: "High Availability for Render Postgres"
        *   Description: Introductory text explaining that HA automatically swaps to a standby database when the primary database encounters an issue.
        *   HA Enablement Information: Explains how to enable High Availability for any Render Postgres database with the required specs. Describes that Render maintains a standby database instance that asynchronously replicates the state of your primary instance. An illustration depicting this setup is included.
        *   Geographic Separation Explanation: Describes that the standby runs in the same region as the primary but is geographically separated to maximize availability.
        *   Failover Explanation: Describes that Render detects critical issues causing primary instance unavailability and automatically fails over to the standby. An illustration depicting failover is included.
        *   Post-Failover Information: Explains that the process takes a few seconds for the standby to become the new primary, and when the degraded instance recovers, it becomes the new standby.
        *   Standby Instance Information: Explains the standby instance configuration in relation to the primary instance and billing.
        *   Prerequisites: Describes the requirements to support high availability, which include using a Pro or Accelerated instance type and PostgreSQL version 13 or later. Provides information on prerequisites for legacy instance types.
        *   Setup: Provides information on setting up high availability. A warning indicates that enabling HA requires a database restart and provides steps to enable HA in the Render Dashboard.
        *   Failover: Defines failover as swapping the primary database for the standby. Describes that Render performs automatic failover and that users can also perform a manual failover.
        *   Automatic Failover: Details how Render automatically triggers failover and possible causes for primary instance unavailability.
        *   Manual Failover: Explains manual failover usage for testing and compliance. Provides information on how to trigger it from the Render Dashboard.
        *   Reconnecting After a Failover: Describes how clients should reconnect after a failover.
        *   Limitations of HA: Describes limitations such as increased latency and the potential for data loss.
   *   Right-Side Navigation: List of links including "Copy page", "Prerequisites", "Setup", "Failover", "Automatic failover", "Manual failover", "Reconnecting after a failover", "Limitations of HA". Contains a link "Did this page help?".
   *   Footer: Contains links to "Pricing", "Blog", "Security", "Customers", and "Careers", and a copyright notice.

3. Interactive Elements:
   *   Header: Contains a search field for searching the documentation. "Sign In" and "Get Started" buttons link to authentication pages.
   *   Sidebar Navigation: List of links navigating to different documentation pages.
   *   Main Content:
        *   Links to "High Availability (HA)", "required specs", "Render Dashboard", "Info page", and "Limitations of HA".
        *   Within Setup: toggle switch to enable/disable High Availability.
        *   Link: "Trigger Failover" under the High Availability section.
   *   Right-Side Navigation: List of links navigating to different sections of the same documentation page.
   *   Right-Side Navigation: "Did this page help?" link.
   *   Footer: Contains links navigating to pages like "Pricing", "Blog", "Security", "Customers", and "Careers".

4. Content Details:
   *   Heading: "High Availability for Render Postgres"
   *   Introductory Text: "Automatically swap to a standby database when your primary encounters an issue."
   *   HA Enablement Text: "You can enable High Availability (HA) for any Render Postgres database with the required specs."
   *   Standby Instance Description: "When you enable HA, Render maintains a separate standby instance of your database that asynchronously replicates the state of your primary instance:"
   *   Geographic Separation Explanation: "The standby runs in the same region as the primary, but in a different "zone" that's geographically separate from the primary (on the order of tens of kilometers). This separation helps to maximize availability in the event of a major disruption."
   *   Automatic Failover Explanation: "If a critical issue causes your primary instance to become unavailable for 30 seconds, Render detects this and automatically fails over to the standby to keep you up and running:"
   *   Post-Failover Text: "This process takes a few seconds, after which the standby instance becomes the new primary (now hosted at the same URL as the original primary). When the degraded instance becomes healthy again, it becomes the new standby."
   *   Standby Instance Billing Information: "Your standby instance always has the same instance type and storage as your primary instance and is billed accordingly."
   *   Prerequisites Heading: "Prerequisites"
   *   Prerequisites List:
        *   "Use a Pro or Accelerated instance type"
        *   "Use PostgreSQL version 13 or later"
   *  Legacy Instance Type Prerequisites: "If your database uses a legacy instance type, it must: Use the Pro instance type or higher, Use PostgreSQL version 13 or later"
   *   Setup Heading: "Setup"
   *   Database Restart Warning: "Enabling HA requires a database restart! Your database will be unavailable temporarily (usually for less than five minutes). Schedule your activation of this feature accordingly."
   *   Setup Steps:
        *   "In the Render Dashboard, select your database and open its Info page."
        *   "Scroll down to the High Availability section and toggle the switch:"
        *   "A confirmation dialog appears. Review the details and then click Enable HA."
        *   "That's it! Your database will restart with HA enabled."
   *   Failover Heading: "Failover"
   *   Failover Definition: "Failover refers to the process of swapping out your primary database instance for your standby instance."
   *   Automatic/Manual Failover Explanation: "Render performs failover automatically when your primary instance becomes unavailable, and you can perform a manual failover for testing purposes. In all cases, failover takes just a few seconds, after which your other services can reconnect to your database."
   *   Automatic Failover Heading: "Automatic failover"
   *   Automatic Failover Description: "Render automatically triggers a failover to your database's standby instance whenever your primary instance becomes unavailable for 30 seconds."
   *   Reasons for Primary Instance Unavailability:
        *   "The node running the instance becomes unresponsive or goes down."
        *   "A network disruption prevents communication with the instance."
        *   "The PostgreSQL process itself crashes."
   *   Manual Failover Heading: "Manual failover"
   *   Manual Failover Intended Use: "Manual failover is intended for testing and compliance purposes. Automatic failover handles scenarios where your primary instance becomes unavailable."
   *   Manual Failover Triggering: "You can manually trigger a failover to your database's standby instance from the Render Dashboard. You might want to do this to test out reconnection behavior for your apps, or to demonstrate failover capabilities for compliance purposes. Go to your database's Info page and click Trigger Fallover under the High Availability section:"
   *   Manual Failover Data Loss: "Performing a manual failover with a healthy primary instance almost never causes any loss of data. It's possible (but unlikely) that changes to your primary instance in the last few seconds before the failover will be lost."
   *   Reconnecting After a Failover Heading: "Reconnecting after a failover"
   *   Reconnection Instructions: "Whenever a failover occurs (automatic or manual), all active connections to your primary instance are terminated. Clients need to reconnect to the new primary instance, which becomes reachable at the exact same database URL. To enable reconnection, make sure your clients include retry functionality in their connection logic."
   *   Limitations of HA Heading: "Limitations of HA"
   *   Limitations List:
        *   "HA increases your database's response latency by approximately 1 millisecond."
        *   "This is because Render operates a proxy in front of the database to identify connectivity issues and trigger failovers."
        *   "Render runs your primary and standby instances on geographically separated nodes in the same region. In the unlikely event that both nodes are affected by an incident, your database will experience downtime."
        *   "When an automatic failover occurs, a small number of the most recent writes to your degraded primary instance might not be represented in your standby instance. These changes are lost."
        *   "This is because data is replicated asynchronously, and the primary might not have pushed the most recent writes to the standby before the degradation occurred."
        *   "A manual failover almost never results in lost changes, but it's possible that changes to your primary instance in the last few seconds before the failover will be lost."
        *   "Failover isn't possible if your standby instance isn't available. This might occur for one of the following reasons: The standby is affected by the same severe incident as the primary, The standby is affected by an unrelated, simultaneous incident, Render is performing routine maintenance on the standby, An incident occurs shortly after a previous failover occurred, and the degraded instance has not yet become healthy, An incident occurs shortly after you initialize your primary database (before the standby is also initialized)."
        *   "You can't connect to a HA database's standby instance or use it for query scaling purposes. For this use case, instead create a read replica."

1. Page Overview: Documentation page explaining how to use preview environments in Render. The page provides instructions, code snippets, and explanations of various features and configurations.

The "Operational Controls" section is expanded, revealing links such as "Infrastructure as Code," "Preview Environments," and "Transform Provider".
    *   Main Content: Contains the core documentation about Preview Environments.
        *   Heading: "Preview Environments" followed by descriptive text: "Test proposed changes in a disposable copy of your production environment."
        *   Requirement: A statement indicating "Preview environments require a Professional workspace or higher."
        *   Explanation: Text explaining the benefits of using preview environments.
        *   "Getting started" Section: Provides a numbered list of steps.
            1.  Make sure your services and databases are defined in a `render.yaml` file. Includes a link to the Render Dashboard. Offers a link to Render Blueprints.
            2.  Enable preview environment generation.  Refers to setting the `preview.generation` key to either "manual" or "automatic".
            3.  Merge changes into the Blueprint linked branch. Includes links to view the deployment and a button to merge the pull request. Mentions GitLab support for status updates.
        *   Warning: Important information regarding explicitly setting a branch for services in `render.yaml`.
        *   Warning: Information about deploying a branch that would be used to create a preview environment.
        *   "Manual vs. automatic preview environments" Section: A table comparing manual and automatic preview environments, explaining their behavior.
        *    "Override preview instance types" Section: Describes how to use different instance types for preview environments. Includes code snippets and a warning about Flexible Postgres databases. Contains a link to the Blueprint YAML reference.
        *   "Override number of preview instances" Section: Explains how to configure the number of instances for preview environments. Includes code snippets and a link to the Blueprint YAML reference.
        *   "Environment variables" Section: Explains how to override environment variables in preview environments.
        *   "Placeholder environment variables" Section: Describes how to use placeholder environment variables, including instructions to manually create an environment group in the Dashboard. Includes a code snippet and a warning about using blueprints.
        *   "Preview environment initialization" Section: Explains how to run custom initialization on subsequent deploys. Includes a code snippet and refers to the `initialDeployHook`.
        *   "Automatic expiration" Section: Describes how to configure automatic expiration for preview environments. Includes a code snippet, and refers to setting the `previewExpirationDays` property.
        *   "Root directory and build filters" Section: Explains how to define root directories or specify build filters.
        *   "Preview environment billing" Section: Explains how preview resources are billed and links to Render Pricing.
    *   Footer: Contains links to "Pricing", "Blog", "Security", "Customers", "Careers", and a copyright notice.

This is an integration detail page for the Linear platform, specifically showcasing the integration with "Orca Security." Its primary purpose is to inform users about the functionality, benefits, and setup instructions for this particular integration, and to encourage engagement with the integrated product. It also provides options for navigating the Linear website and exploring other integrations.

**1. Page Overview:**
This page describes "Vercel Agent," an AI-powered product designed to enhance code review and automate incident investigation for shipping software on Vercel. Its primary purpose is to inform users about the product's capabilities and benefits, encouraging them to begin using the service.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Header Navigation:**
    *   **Primary Product Navigation:** Includes a Vercel logo (linking to the Vercel homepage), followed by links for "Products" (with a dropdown menu), "Resources" (with a dropdown menu), "Solutions" (with a dropdown menu), "Enterprise," and "Pricing."
    *   **User Utility Navigation:** Includes "Log In," "Contact," and a "Sign Up" call-to-action button.
    *   **Sub-Product Navigation:** Specific to "Vercel Agent," including "Overview" (indicating the current page), "Setup," and "Docs."

*   **Hero Section:**
    *   **Main Heading:** "The intelligence layer for shipping on Vercel."
    *   **Descriptive Text:** "AI that reviews PRs, investigates anomalies, and proposes fixes so you stay in flow."
    *   **Call-to-Action:** A button labeled "Get Started."

*   **AI Code Review Section:**
    *   **Section Heading:** "AI code review with standards as high as yours."
    *   **Introductory Text:** Explains the challenges developers face with increasing code generation and inefficient review processes.
    *   **Feature Description: "Full-context PR reviews."**
        *   **Purpose:** The Agent analyzes diffs within the application context to identify security and performance issues and suggest fixes.
        *   **Example Data Display:** A table showing "repo/workflow" examples with corresponding "Suggestions," "Review Time," and "Files Read" metrics.
    *   **Feature Description: "High-quality suggestions."**
        *   **Purpose:** Patches are run and validated in sandboxes to ensure high-quality, ready-to-ship code.
        *   **Example Interface Snippet:** A visual representation of a pull request ("Adding observability and events #53417") showing a "Vercel bot" initiation and a progress indicator with a "Commit suggestion" button.

*   **Automated Anomaly Investigation Section:**
    *   **Section Heading:** "Anomalies, investigated automatically."
    *   **Introductory Text:** Describes how Agent investigations streamline incident response, reducing alert fatigue and context switching.
    *   **Feature Description: "Signal-to-noise reduction."**
        *   **Purpose:** The Agent investigates activity spikes to differentiate normal behavior from actual issues.
        *   **Example Data Visualization:** A line graph illustrating an "5xx /api/auth error rate increased to 42%" over a 12-hour period, accompanied by an "Investigating..." status.
    *   **Feature Description: "Intelligent remediation."**
        *   **Purpose:** The Agent performs root-cause analysis specific to the tech stack and offers actionable steps for faster incident resolution.
        *   **Investigation Summary:** A list of key findings from an AI investigation, such as "Acme API has been unavailable...", "42% of requests failed...", "no deployments were made...", and "The service automatically recovered after 23 minutes."

*   **Impact Tracking Section:**
    *   **Section Heading:** "It comes with receipts."
    *   **Descriptive Text:** States that the system tracks suggestions, time saved, and overall improvements, supported by data.
    *   **Data Visualization:** A bar chart titled "Suggestions Made" depicting activity over time. A partially visible chart related to "Costs Saved" is also present.

*   **Frequently Asked Questions Section:**
    *   **Section Heading:** "Frequently Asked Questions."
    *   **List of Questions:** Presents a collection of common questions, each with an interactive element to reveal or hide its answer. Questions include: "How does Vercel Agent validate improvements?", "Does it work with my framework?", "How is it priced?", "Does it train on my code?", and "Does it require a seat license?".

*   **Footer:**
    *   **Categorized Navigation Links:** Organized under headings: "Products" (e.g., AI, Enterprise, Next.js), "Resources" (e.g., Community, Docs, Pricing), "Company" (e.g., About, Careers, Legal), and "Social" (e.g., GitHub, LinkedIn, Twitter, YouTube).
    *   **Status Indicator:** A link labeled "Loading status..."
    *   **Utility Controls:** Includes an interactive element for theme selection (e.g., light/dark mode) and a button to return to the top of the page.

**3. Interactive Elements:**

*   **Navigation Links:** All links within the header and footer provide navigation to other pages or sections.
*   **Dropdown Menus:** "Products," "Resources," "Solutions" in the header and "SDKs by Vercel" in the footer expand to reveal additional links.
*   **Call-to-Action Buttons:** "Sign Up" in the header and "Get Started" in the hero section are intended to initiate user onboarding or product access.
*   **Expandable FAQ Items:** Each question in the FAQ section can be clicked to toggle the visibility of its corresponding answer.
*   **Theme Toggle Button:** Allows users to switch between different visual themes.
*   **Scroll-to-Top Button:** Facilitates returning to the top of the page.

**4. Content Details:**

*   **Headings and Subheadings:** Clearly define the purpose and content of each section and sub-section.
*   **Descriptive Paragraphs:** Provide context and explanation for the product's features and benefits.
*   **Tabular Data:** Presents specific metrics related to code review (e.g., suggestions, review time, files read).
*   **Graphical Data:** Utilizes line graphs (e.g., error rate) and bar charts (e.g., suggestions made) to visualize trends and impact.
*   **Informational Lists:** Summarize key findings or benefits, such as the details of an AI investigation.

1. Page Overview: Documentation page explaining Render private services. The page describes what private services are, how they differ from web services, and when to use them. It also includes examples and links to related documentation.

2. Sections:
    *   Header: Contains links to "Docs", "Changelog", a search input, a link to "Ask AI", a "Sign In" link, and a "Get Started" button.
    *   Sidebar Navigation: Contains hierarchical navigation for the Render documentation, with sections such as "Start", "Service Types", "Deploys", "Git providers", and "Docker images". Items within "Service Types" include "Which to use?", "Static sites", "Web services", "Private services", "Background workers", "Cron jobs", "Workflows", and "Multi-service architectures".
    *   Main Content:
        *   Heading: "Private Services"
        *   Subheading: "Host apps that only accept traffic from your other services."
        *   Explanation of private services and how they differ from web services regarding public internet access and subdomains. It includes a diagram illustrating the connectivity between external clients, web services, and private services, highlighting the private network connection.
        *   Text explaining that private services are reachable by other Render services on the same private network, making them ideal for internal infrastructure needs.
        *   Text stating that private services can listen on any port and communicate using any protocol.
        *   Information section: "Private services must bind to at least one port." Includes a suggestion to create a background worker if the service won't receive incoming traffic.
        *   Heading: "Examples"
        *   List of example deployment guides: "Deploy an Elasticsearch server" and "Deploy Clickhouse"
        *   Heading: "Private service or background worker?"
        *   Explanation of the difference between private services and background workers regarding their reachability via the private network. It includes a diagram illustrating the connectivity between web services, private services, and background workers.
        *   List:
            *   If your internal service will bind to at least one port and receive private network traffic, create a private service.
            *   Otherwise, create a background worker.
        *   Text describing background workers and their use cases.
        *   Heading: "Connect to your private service"
        *   Link to "Private Network Communication"

    *   Right Sidebar:
        *   "Copy page" button
        *   "Private Services"
        *   "Examples"
        *   "Private service or background worker?"
        *   "Connect to your private service"
        *   "Did this page help?" button

    *   Footer: Contains links to "Pricing", "Blog", "Security", "Customers", and "Careers", and copyright information.

3. Interactive Elements:

    *   "Get Started" button: Navigates to a registration or onboarding page.

4. Content Details:
    *   Main heading: "Private Services"
    *   Descriptive text: "Host apps that only accept traffic from your other services."
    *   Text: "Render private services are just like web services, with one exception: private services aren't reachable via the public internet. They do not receive an onrender.com subdomain:"
    *   Text: "However, private services are reachable by your other Render services on the same private network! This means they're perfect for services that only your own infrastructure needs to talk to."
    *   Text: "Private services can listen on almost any port (see details) and communicate using any protocol."
    *   Information box title: "Private services must bind to at least one port."
    *   Information box text: "If your service won't receive incoming traffic, instead create a background worker. See details below."
    *   "Examples" heading.
    *   "Here are some deployment guides for tools that make great private services:"
    *   List items: "Deploy an Elasticsearch server", "Deploy Clickhouse"
    *   "Private service or background worker?" heading.
    *   "Like private services, your background workers are unreachable via the public internet. Unlike private services, background workers aren't even reachable via their private network:"
    *   List:
        *   "If your internal service will bind to at least one port and receive private network traffic, create a private service."
        *   "Otherwise, create a background worker."
    *   Text: "Background workers can send private network requests to other services but can't receive them. They usually perform long-running or resource-intensive tasks, which they fetch from a job queue that's often backed by a Render Key Value instance."
    *   "Connect to your private service" heading.
    *   "See Private Network Communication."

**1. Page Overview:**
This is a documentation page providing a detailed functional explanation of Render's Private Network feature. Its primary purpose is to inform users how Render services can securely communicate with each other within the same region without public internet exposure, and how to configure and manage this functionality.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Global Header:**
    *   A company logo "Render" which functions as a link, likely to the main website.
    *   Navigation links: "Docs" (active, indicating the current section), and "Changelog".
    *   A search input field labeled "Search the docs" for finding information within the documentation.
    *   A button labeled "Ask AI" which likely provides an AI-powered search or assistance feature.
    *   A "Sign In" button for user authentication.
    *   A "Get Started" button for new users.

*   **Documentation Navigation (Sidebar):**
    *   A hierarchical list of documentation categories and links.
    *   "Datastores" is a collapsible section containing links for: Overview, Creating & connecting, Recovery & backups, Database credentials, Read replicas, High availability, Admin apps, Extensions, Connection pooling, Version upgrades, Troubleshooting performance, Flexible plans, and Legacy instance types.
    *   "Networking" is an expanded section containing links for: Regions, Private network (the currently active page), Private links, Edge caching, WebSockets, Outbound bandwidth, and TLS certificates.
    *   "Custom domains" is a collapsible section containing links for: Overview, Cloudflare, Namecheap, and Other DNS providers.
    *   "IP addresses" is a section containing links for: Outbound IPs and Inbound IP rules.
    *   "Operational Controls" is a collapsible section containing links for: The Render Dashboard and SSH / Shell access.

*   **Main Content - Private Network Description:**
    *   A main heading: "Private Network".
    *   A descriptive subheading: "Communicate securely between services without traversing the public internet."
    *   Body text explaining that Render services in the same region can communicate without public internet traversal.
    *   A diagram illustrating a "Private Network" showing interactions between a "Web Service", "Private Service", "Postgres", "Background Worker", and "Key Value" instances.
    *   A list detailing the characteristics of the private network:
        *   Web services and private services have unique hostnames, can listen on most ports, and use any protocol. Free web services can send but not receive private network requests.
        *   Render Postgres and Key Value instances have internal URLs for private network connections.
        *   Background workers and cron jobs can send private network requests but cannot receive them.
    *   Additional body text describing the speed, safety, reliability of private network communication, including support for direct IP-based communication for advanced cases.
    *   An informational section suggesting "Integrating with AWS PrivateLink" for connecting to non-Render systems.

*   **Port restrictions Section:**
    *   A heading: "Port restrictions".
    *   Body text stating a limit of 75 open ports per service.
    *   A list of specific ports that cannot be used for private network communication: 10000, 18012, 18013, 19099.

*   **What's on my private network? Section:**
    *   A heading: "What's on my private network?".
    *   Body text clarifying that static sites are not included in a private network.
    *   Body text explaining conditions for other Render services to be on the same private network (same region and workspace).
    *   An informational section indicating that professional workspaces or higher allow blocking private network traffic.

*   **How to connect Section:**
    *   A heading: "How to connect".
    *   Body text listing service types that have an internal address or URL: Web services, Private services, Render Postgres databases, and Render Key Value instances.
    *   Body text explaining where to find the internal address in the Render Dashboard's Connect menu, under the Internal tab.
    *   A UI representation showing "Internal Address" details for a web service with an example URL and a copy button.
    *   Body text indicating that private services also display this as "Service Address".
    *   A UI representation for a private service (Elasticsearch) showing "Service Address" with an example URL and a copy button.
    *   An informational section recommending specifying the expected protocol in the internal address string.
    *   Body text explaining that background workers and cron jobs can send but not receive inbound private network traffic.

*   **Integrating with AWS PrivateLink Section:**
    *   A heading: "Integrating with AWS PrivateLink".
    *   Body text describing the capability for Professional workspaces or higher to create secure, low-latency connections to non-Render systems hosted on AWS.
    *   A diagram illustrating the connection between a "Render Private Network" (containing a Web Service and Private Service) and an "AWS VPC" (containing Private Link, MongoDB, Atlas Database, and Snowflake Database).
    *   Body text explaining the use of a private link for connecting to external services like Snowflake or MongoDB Atlas and referencing a "Private Link Connections" link for further details.

*   **Direct IP communication (advanced) Section:**
    *   A heading: "Direct IP communication (advanced)".
    *   An informational section advising to use this method only if hostname-based communication is not suitable.
    *   Body text describing advanced use cases for direct IP communication, such as messaging individual instances for monitoring or implementing custom load balancing.
    *   Body text explaining that web and private services have a "discovery hostname" that resolves to all active instance IPs, with a specific format, and references "How to connect".
    *   Body text indicating that each service exposes its discovery hostname as an environment variable (`RENDER_DISCOVERY_SERVICE`), referencing "Referencing values from other services".

*   **Example: Obtaining instance IPs Section:**
    *   A heading: "Example: Obtaining instance IPs".
    *   Body text introducing a JavaScript function example for fetching and printing instance IP addresses via DNS lookup.
    *   An informational section advising the use of a lookup API relying on the underlying system's DNS resolver.
    *   A code block labeled "JS" containing a JavaScript function (`fetchAndPrintIPs`) that demonstrates how to perform a DNS lookup using a discovery hostname to obtain and display IP addresses.

*   **Feedback Section:**
    *   A button labeled "Did this page help?" which likely initiates a feedback process.

*   **Global Footer:**
    *   Copyright information: "© Render 2025".
    *   Navigation links: Pricing, Blog, Security, Customers, and Careers.

**3. Interactive Elements:**

*   **Links:** "Render" logo, "Docs", "Changelog", all links in the sidebar navigation, "See below", "Free web services", "Professional workspace", "Static sites", "Connect", "Render Dashboard", "Internal tab", "Service Address", "Background workers", "cron jobs", "Professional workspace", "Private Link Connections", "hostname-based communication", "scaled services", "How to connect", "Referencing values from other services", "lookup API", "/etc/resolv.conf", "Pricing", "Blog", "Security", "Customers", "Careers".
*   **Input Fields:** "Search the docs" (text input).
*   **Buttons:** "Ask AI", "Sign In", "Get Started", a "Copy page" button, a copy button associated with the "Internal Address" example, a copy button associated with the "Service Address" example, "Did this page help?".
*   **Collapsible/Expandable Sections:** "Datastores", "Networking", "Custom domains", "Operational Controls" in the sidebar navigation.

**4. Content Details:**

*   **Headings:** "Private Network", "Port restrictions", "What's on my private network?", "How to connect", "Integrating with AWS PrivateLink", "Direct IP communication (advanced)", "Example: Obtaining instance IPs".
*   **Key Data/Information:**
    *   Description of Render's private network capabilities.
    *   Service types included in the private network: Web services, Private services, Render Postgres databases, Render Key Value instances, Background workers, Cron jobs.
    *   Port restriction details: 75 open ports maximum, specific forbidden ports (10000, 18012, 18013, 19099).
    *   Conditions for services to be on the same private network (region, workspace).
    *   Requirement of "Professional workspace" for certain features (blocking traffic, AWS PrivateLink).
    *   Location of internal addresses in the Render Dashboard.
    *   Examples of internal URLs/addresses (e.g., `http my-web-service-3m9z:10000`, `elasticsearch-2i3e.9200`).
    *   Use cases for direct IP communication (monitoring, custom load balancing).
    *   Discovery hostname format (e.g., `[INTERNAL_HOSTNAME]-discovery`).
    *   Environment variable for discovery hostname (`RENDER_DISCOVERY_SERVICE`).
    *   JavaScript code snippet demonstrating DNS lookup for IP addresses.

1. Page Overview:
This is a documentation page describing service metrics within the Render platform. The purpose is to explain the various metrics available, how they are calculated, and how they can be used to monitor application and database performance.

2. Sections:
    *   Header: Contains navigational elements including links to Docs and Changelog, a search input, links to Sign In and Get Started.
    *   Sidebar: A list of links, including "Operational Controls", "Infrastructure as Code", "Monitoring & Logs" (with sub-items like "Health checks", "Notifications", "Metrics", "Logging"), "Integrations", and "User Management". Selecting an item navigates to the corresponding section.
    *   Page Title and Description: A title "Service Metrics" and a description of the page's purpose: "Visualize the performance of your apps and datastores".
    *   Streaming Render Service Metrics: Contains an introductory paragraph and a link to "See Streaming Render Service Metrics"
    *   Available Metrics: An introduction paragraph explaining which graphs are shown. A table displays "Metric(s)" and "Which services?", including metrics like "CPU and memory usage", "Disk storage", "HTTP requests", "Outbound bandwidth", and "Database activity".
    *   CPU and Memory Usage: Includes a description of where to display service's CPU and memory. It also contains "Application Metrics", a selector to choose an instance from "All", an "Aggregations" selector, and a "Percentage" selector. Includes a graph of application metrics. The section ends with a list of ways to customize the graphs.
    *   Disk Storage: Includes a description and list of disk-related metrics for "Render Postgres databases", "Render Key Value instances", and "services with attached persistent disk." It also includes a table showing "Metric" and "Description" for "Disk Usage", "Disk Activity", and "Disk Operations".

## Functional Description of Render Documentation Page

### 1. Page Overview
This is a documentation page on the Render platform, specifically an FAQ addressing the transition from Redis to Valkey for Key Value instances. Its primary purpose is to inform users about the change, explain what Valkey is, how it impacts their services, and address common questions regarding migration and pricing.

### 2. Sections

**A. Global Header**
*   **Site Logo:** A logo representing "Render".
*   **Main Navigation Links:**
    *   "Docs" link, indicating the current section.
    *   "Changelog" link.
*   **Utility Elements:**
    *   **Search Input Field:** Labeled "Search the docs", allows users to search documentation content.
    *   **"Ask AI" Button:** Provides an interactive way to get answers.
    *   **"Sign In" Link:** Directs users to the account login page.
    *   **"Get Started" Button:** A call-to-action for new users to begin using the platform.

**B. Sidebar Navigation**
A hierarchical navigation structure for the documentation:
*   **Expandable Sections:** Each section has a title and an indicator to expand or collapse its sub-items.
    *   "Deploys" section (collapsed). Includes a "Default environment variables" link.
    *   "Workflows" section (collapsed). Displays an "EA" tag, likely indicating Early Access. Sub-items include "What are workflows?", "Create your first workflow", "Define tasks", "Run tasks", "Local dev", "Example workflows" (external link), and a "SDK reference" section with "Python" link.
    *   "Datastores" section (expanded).
        *   "Persistent disks" link.
        *   "Key Value (Redis®-compatible)" sub-section.
            *   "Creating & connecting" link.
            *   "Valkey/Redis FAQ" link (this current page).
        *   "Postgres databases" sub-section.
            *   "Overview" link.
            *   "Creating & connecting" link.
            *   "Recovery & backups" link.
            *   "Database credentials" link.
            *   "Read replicas" link.
            *   "High availability" link.
            *   "Admin apps" link.
            *   "Extensions" link.
            *   "Connection pooling" link.
            *   "Version upgrades" link.
            *   "Troubleshooting performance" link.
            *   "Flexible plans" link.
            *   "Legacy instance types" link.
    *   "Networking" section (collapsed). Includes a "Regions" link.

**C. Main Content Area (FAQ: Valkey on Render)**
This section provides detailed information about Valkey on Render.
*   **Page Title:** "FAQ: Valkey on Render"
*   **Subtitle:** "New Render Key Value instances run Valkey instead of Redis®."
*   **Introductory Text:** Explains that Render adopted Valkey in place of Redis for all newly created instances of "Render Key Value". Includes a link to "Render Key Value".
*   **Statement on Existing Instances:** Clarifies that "Existing Redis instances continue operating as usual" with a link to "See details below" for more information.
*   **Main FAQ Heading:** "FAQ"
*   **Question and Answer Sections:** A series of headings representing questions, each followed by a text answer.
    *   **Question: "What is Valkey?"**
        *   Answer: Describes Valkey as an open-source, Redis-compatible key-value store that originated as a fork of Redis. Explains its drop-in replacement nature and independence from Redis.
    *   **Question: "Why has Render adopted Valkey for new Key Value instances?"**
        *   Answer: Explains the licensing changes for Redis in 2024 (linking to "Redis Source Available License") and how this led to the creation and adoption of Valkey by Render.
    *   **Question: "How do I create a Valkey instance?"**
        *   Answer: Describes the creation process as identical to Redis instances. Mentions using a `render.yaml` "Blueprint file" (linking to it) and that "keyvalue" and "redis" are equivalent values for a service type.
    *   **Question: "What will happen to my existing Redis instances?"**
        *   Answer:
            *   States that "Redis instances will no longer receive version updates" and will remain on version 6.2.14.
            *   States that "You cannot create new Redis instances, with one exception". The exception is for "Preview environments" (linking to them) to replicate existing instances.
    *   **Question: "Do I need to migrate my existing Redis instances to Valkey?"**
        *   Answer: States that migration is not required but is an option for users, as Valkey is a drop-in replacement.
    *   **Question: "Are there any changes to pricing?"**
        *   Answer: States that Key Value instance types, specs, and pricing remain unchanged; only the underlying technology is different.
*   **Disclaimer:** A statement about Redis being a registered trademark and Render Inc.'s ownership of its rights, clarifying that the content is for referential purposes only and does not imply sponsorship or affiliation.

**D. Contextual Utility Section**
*   **"Copy page" Dropdown:** Allows users to copy the page content.
*   **"FAQ: Valkey on Render" Heading.**
*   **Internal Navigation List (Table of Contents):** A list of links corresponding to the main questions in the content area, allowing for quick navigation within the page.
    *   "What is Valkey?"
    *   "Why has Render adopted Valkey for new Key Value instances?"
    *   "How do I create a Valkey instance?"
    *   "What will happen to my existing Redis instances?"
    *   "Do I need to migrate my existing Redis instances to Valkey?"
    *   "Are there any changes to pricing?"
*   **"Did this page help?" Button:** Provides a feedback mechanism for the documentation.

**E. Global Footer**
*   **Site-wide Navigation Links:**
    *   "Pricing"
    *   "Blog"
    *   "Security"
    *   "Customers"
    *   "Careers"
*   **Copyright Information:** "© Render 2025"

**F. Global Page Controls**
*   **Light/Dark Mode Toggle:** A button with a sun icon, likely to switch the page's theme.

### 3. Interactive Elements
*   **Search Input Field:** Allows text input for searching documentation.
*   **"Ask AI" Button:** Initiates an AI-powered query or dialog.
*   **"Sign In" Link:** Navigates to the user login page.
*   **"Get Started" Button:** Navigates to a new user onboarding or signup page.
*   **Sidebar Section Expand/Collapse Indicators:** Icons next to section titles that toggle the visibility of sub-items.
*   **Sidebar Navigation Links:** Navigates to other documentation pages or sections.
*   **"Copy page" Dropdown:** Provides options related to copying the page content.
*   **Internal Links within Main Content:** Links like "Render Key Value", "See details below", "Redis Source Available license", "Blueprint file", and "Preview environments" navigate to related documentation or external resources.

1. Page Overview: Documentation page about the Live View feature for Kernel browsers. The purpose is to explain how to access and customize the live view of Kernel browsers.

    *   **Main Content:**
        *   A heading "Live View."
        *   Introductory text explaining the purpose of the Live View feature.
        *   Text explaining how to access the Live View feature using the `browser_live_view_url`.
        *   Code example showing how to obtain the `browser_live_view_url` in Typescript/Javascript and Python. The code includes the import of Kernel, creation of a new Kernel instance, creation of a browser instance, and displaying the browser's live view URL.
        *   A section about "Query parameters" with information on customizing the live view using parameters. It explains the `readonly` parameter. It gives an example URL with the `readonly` parameter set to true.
        *   A section about "Embedding in an iframe" describing how to embed the live view in an iframe. It provides an example iframe tag.
        *   A section about "Kiosk mode" describing how to enable kiosk mode by setting the `kiosk_mode` parameter to true. It provides a code example showing how to set the `kiosk_mode` parameter in Typescript/Javascript and Python.
        *   A section about "URL lifetime" explaining that the `browser_live_view_url` becomes invalid when the browser is deleted or times out.
    *   **Pagination:** A section with links to "Viewports" (previous) and "Standby Mode" (next).
    *   **Footer:** Contains links to Terms of Service, GitHub, LinkedIn and mentions it's Powered by mintlify.
    *   **Right Section:** Contains "On this page" and a list with the following options: Query parameters, Embedding in an iframe, Kiosk mode and URL lifetime.

    *   The header has a search input.
    *   The main content has a code example with copy functionality and expand functionality.
    *   Links in the navigation section navigate to different documentation pages.
    *   The pagination section has links to the previous and next pages.
    *   A “Copy page” button.
    *   Ask a question input field.
    *   Links to Terms of Service, GitHub, and LinkedIn.

4. Content Details:
    *   Page Heading: "Live View"
    *   Introductory text: "Humans-in-the-loop can access the live view of Kernel browsers in real-time to resolve errors or take unscripted actions."
    *   Code Examples (Typescript/Javascript and Python): show how to obtain the `browser_live_view_url`.
    *   Parameter Description: `readonly` (bool): when set to `true`, the view will be non-interactive.
    *   Iframe Example: `<iframe src={browser.browser_live_view_url}></iframe>`
    *   Kiosk Mode Description: Explanation of kiosk mode and the `kiosk_mode` parameter.
    *   URL Lifetime explanation: `browser_live_view_url` becomes invalid once the browser is `deleted` manually or via timeout.
    *   Navigation links: Direct to various documentation pages.
    *   Example URL: `https://api.onkernel.com/browser/live/<TOKEN>?readOnly=true`

    *   Introductory text: Describes Magnitude as an open source AI browser automation framework, explains its function, and mentions integration with Kernel.
    *   Section Title: Adding Kernel to existing Magnitude implementations
    *   Section Text: Explains that the section is for users who have existing Magnitude implementations and want to switch to Kernel's cloud browsers.
    *   Step 1 Title: Install the Kernel SDK
    *   Code Snippet: `npm install @onkernel/sdk`
    *   Step 2 Title: Initialize Kernel and create a browser
    *   Step 2 Text: Import the libraries and create a cloud browser session:

Its primary purpose is to inform users about OpenAGI Lux, provide step-by-step instructions for setup, outline the benefits of using it with Kernel, and suggest further learning resources.
