## Functional Description of Importer Documentation Page

**1. Page Overview:**
This is a documentation page providing instructions and best practices for importing data into the Linear application from various external services. Its primary purpose is to guide users through the entire import process.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Global Header Area:**
    *   Includes a product logo functioning as a link to the main "Docs" section.
    *   A search input field is available for documentation search.
    *   A breadcrumb trail indicates the current page location: `Administration / Importer`.
    *   Contains navigational links: `Linear Concepts`, `Pre-import best practices`, `How to import`.
    *   A "Copy page" button is present, allowing users to copy the page content.
    *   A "Sign up" button is present, likely for new user registration or accessing the product.
    *   Identifies the current user by a display name, "Tony Hoang".

*   **Primary Navigation Menu (Sidebar):**
    *   A search input field for navigating the documentation.
    *   An expandable list of documentation categories, each containing sub-links:
        *   `Getting started` (expandable)
        *   `Account` (expandable)
        *   `Your sidebar` (expandable)
        *   `Administration` (expanded)
            *   `Workspaces` (link)
            *   `Login methods` (link)
            *   `Invite members` (link)
            *   `Members and roles` (link)
            *   `Security` (link)
            *   `SAML` (link)
            *   `SCIM` (link)
            *   `API and Webhooks` (link)
            *   `Third-Party App Approvals` (link)
            *   `Billing and plans` (link)
            *   `Audit log` (link)
            *   `Importer` (currently active page link)
            *   `Exporting Data` (link)
        *   `Teams` (expandable)
        *   `Issues` (expandable)
        *   `Issue properties` (expandable)
        *   `Projects and Initiatives` (expandable)
        *   `Cycles` (expandable)
        *   `Views` (expandable)
        *   `Find and filter` (expandable)
        *   `API` (expandable)
    *   A "Linear Developers" link.
    *   A "Contact support" link.

*   **Main Content Area - "Importer" Section:**
    *   A main heading: "Importer".
    *   Introductory text describing the purpose of the page: "Learn best practices for importing to Linear. See the table of contents for specific instructions."
    *   An illustrative content area featuring icons that typically represent external services (e.g., GitHub, Figma, Google Drive), implying integration or data transfer capabilities.
    *   **"Linear Concepts" Subsection:**
        *   Provides definitions of core Linear concepts relevant to importing, such as "Linear workspace", "teams", "Issues and projects", and "Initiatives".
        *   Mentions considerations for data translation during import from source tools.
    *   **"Pre-import best practices" Subsection:**
        *   A heading: "Pre-import best practices".
        *   Introductory text: "Consider the below before starting your first import."
        *   **"Which data is worth importing?" Sub-subsection:**
            *   Text discussing how to evaluate the relevance of historical data and when to perform a "clean break" versus full historical record.
            *   Recommends piloting imports with a few test teams and provides a link to "switch instruction manual".
    *   **"Choose an import method" Sub-subsection:**
        *   Describes two import methods: dedicated import assistants for specific products and a CLI import tool.
        *   Mentions specific tools with dedicated assistants (Jira, GitHub Issues, Asana, Shortcut) and indicates the CLI importer is available for others.
        *   A link to "here" for more information on the CLI importer.
    *   **"Understand the import process" Sub-subsection:**
        *   Describes the general import process in steps.
        *   A data table with two sections, "Step" and "Detail", outlining the stages of an import:
            *   `Setup`: Providing access tokens, creating teams, and managing permissions.
            *   `Review`: Fetching and displaying issue, label, user, and other data.
            *   `Choose what to import`: Selecting issues to import or archive.
            *   `Map users`: Mapping fetched users to existing or new Linear users.
            *   `Confirm`: Summarizing data and initiating the import.
    *   **"How to import" Section:**
        *   A heading: "How to import".
        *   Introductory text: "Find instructions on importing from your source tool below."
        *   **"Jira" Sub-subsection:**
            *   A link to "instructions here".
        *   **"GitHub Issues" Sub-subsection:**
            *   A link to "instructions here".
        *   **"Asana" Sub-subsection:**
            *   A numbered list of steps for importing from Asana:
                1.  Navigate to `Settings > Administration > Importer` to access the page.
                2.  Click the button for Asana.
                3.  Enter an Asana personal access token (with a link to "developer console" for obtaining it).
                4.  Enter the Linear team name.
                5.  Select which Linear team to import issues into.
                6.  Click `Next` to start importing.
            *   Information about how issues are assigned and handling multiple Asana projects.
            *   An informational message: "We currently only support in app importing from Asana organizations where your Asana workspace is an organization, and where your Asana workspace to an organization in Linear. If your Asana workspace is not an organization, you will need to use the CLI importer."
            *   A data table mapping Asana fields to Linear fields:
                *   `Priority` -> `Priority`
                *   `Notes` -> `Issue description (converted to Markdown)`
                *   `Attached files` -> `Added to description, all files except images and videos are converted to links`
                *   `Tags` -> `Labels (team-level)`
                *   `Assignee` -> `Assignee`
                *   `Projects` -> `Projects`
                *   `Comments` -> `Comments (markdown respected)`
                *   `Status` -> `Imported status will be mapped to Backlog or Done only`
                *   `Sub-issue` -> `Sub-issue`
                *   `Blocked/blocking` -> `Blocked/blocking`
        *   **"Shortcut" Sub-subsection:**
            *   A numbered list of steps for importing from Shortcut (similar to Asana, requiring admin privileges for import/export settings).
            *   A data table mapping Shortcut fields to Linear fields:
                *   `Name` -> `Title`
                *   `Description` -> `Issue description`
                *   `Tasks` -> `Appended to the description`
                *   `External tickets` -> `Appended to the description`
                *   `State` -> `Mapped to the most similar Linear status`
                *   `Story type` -> `Added as label (team-level)`
                *   `Tags` -> `Added as label (team-level)`
                *   `Owners` -> `First owner added as assignee when possible`
                *   `Epic` -> `Created as project`
                *   `Comments` -> `Comments`
                *   `Estimate` -> `Estimate`
                *   `Due date` -> `Due date`
                *   `Priority` -> `Priority`
        *   **"Trello, Pivotal Tracker, GitLab Issues" Sub-subsection:**
            *   Instructions to use the open source CLI Importer for these services.
            *   Specific notes for Trello imports (must be run from individual board exports, not overall workspace).
            *   Information about CLI imports not supporting data not supported by import assistants (e.g., comments, projects).
            *   A link to "Command Line Interface (CLI) tool" and instructions for accessing it via `Settings > Workspace > Import/Export`.
            *   A link to "this video" for help with CLI imports.
        *   **"Linear" Sub-subsection:**
            *   Instructions for importing data between Linear workspaces, requiring admin credentials in both workspaces.
            *   A numbered list of steps for importing from Linear:
                1.  Navigate to `Settings > Administration > Importer` to access the page.
                2.  Click the "Linear to Linear import" button.
                3.  Select the source workspace.
                4.  Select the teams to import.
                5.  Choose how to map members.
                6.  Review a summary of the import.
                7.  Click "Start import".
            *   An informational message listing data that will NOT be transferred during a Linear to Linear import (e.g., custom views, integrations, billing/plans, workspace URL, personal and workspace settings).
            *   A note on how roles are handled during transfer.
            *   A data table mapping Linear (old) fields to Linear (new) fields:
                *   `Title` -> `Title`
                *   `Description` -> `Description`
                *   `Estimate` -> `Estimate`
                *   `Labels` -> `Labels`
                *   `Due date` -> `Due date`
                *   `Comments` -> `Comments`
                *   `Workflow state` -> `Workflow state`
                *   `Sub-issues` -> `Sub-issues`
                *   `Relationships` -> `Relationships`
                *   `Projects` -> `Projects`
                *   `Initiatives` -> `Initiatives`
                *   `Team templates` -> `Team templates`
                *   `Dashboards` -> `Dashboards`
        *   **"Other" Sub-subsection:**
            *   Instructions for importing from unlisted tools using the CLI Importer with a CSV file.
            *   Steps for generating a Linear export file format.
            *   A list of fields to paste data from a source CSV into:
                *   `Title` - Issue title
                *   `Description` - Issue description
                *   `Priority` - Issue priority
                *   `Status` - Issue state (workflow)
                *   `Assignee` - Issue assignee (user's full name or email)
                *   `Created` - Issue created date
                *   `Completed` - Issue completed timestamp; populates issue activity log.
                *   `Labels` - Added as a label (separate by commas for multiple labels)
                *   `Estimate` - Issue estimate (appears on the issue's team).
            *   Instructions for importing the CSV using the CLI (with a link to "this video").
    *   **"Troubleshooting" Section:**
        *   Heading: "Troubleshooting".
        *   Provides advice if imports do not work as expected, including checking specific sections and contacting `support@linear.app`.
        *   Instructions for deleting an import via `Import/Export` settings.
        *   Information about reimporting from the same external source, which skips already-imported issues.

*   **Page Navigation Footer:**
    *   A navigation element with links to "Previous" page (`Audit log`) and "Next" page (`Exporting Data`).

**3. Interactive Elements:**

*   **Links:**
    *   Logo link to "Docs".
    *   Search input fields in header and sidebar.
    *   `Copy page` button.
    *   `Sign up` button.
    *   Breadcrumb links (`Linear Concepts`, `Pre-import best practices`, `How to import`).
    *   Sidebar navigation links (expandable categories and direct links).
    *   Text links within the main content (e.g., "switch instruction manual", "here" for CLI importer, "instructions here" for Jira/GitHub Issues, "developer console", "Command Line Interface (CLI) tool", "this video", "support@linear.app").
    *   `Next` button in Asana and Shortcut import steps.
    *   `Start import` button in Linear to Linear import steps.
    *   Previous (`Audit log`) and Next (`Exporting Data`) page navigation links.

**4. Content Details:**

*   **Main Headings:** Importer, Linear Concepts, Pre-import best practices, Which data is worth importing?, Choose an import method, Understand the import process, How to import, Jira, GitHub Issues, Asana, Shortcut, Trello, Pivotal Tracker, GitLab Issues, Linear, Other, Troubleshooting.
*   **Lists:** Numbered steps for specific import processes (Asana, Shortcut, Linear to Linear). Bulleted list of fields for CSV import. Bulleted list of data NOT transferred in Linear to Linear import.
*   **Tables:**
    *   "Understand the import process" table with "Step" and "Detail" sections.
    *   Asana field mapping table with "Asana" and "Linear" sections.
    *   Shortcut field mapping table with "Shortcut" and "Linear" sections.
    *   Linear (old) to Linear (new) field mapping table.
*   **Informational Messages:** A message regarding Asana organization requirements and another listing untransferred data for Linear to Linear imports.

**1. Page Overview:**
This page is a product information page for Stripe's integrated financial services offering. Its primary purpose is to inform businesses about how they can launch and embed various financial services directly into their platforms using Stripe, highlighting the benefits, functionalities, and use cases to drive new client acquisition and platform differentiation.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Header:** Contains the Stripe logo (linking to the homepage) and a primary navigation menu with dropdowns for "Productos" (Products), "Soluciones" (Solutions), "Desarrolladores" (Developers), "Recursos" (Resources), and "Tarifas" (Pricing). It also includes secondary navigation links for "Soporte" (Support) and "Iniciar sesión" (Sign In), and a "Contacta con ventas" (Contact Sales) button.
*   **Hero Section:** Features a heading "Lanza servicios financieros en tu plataforma" (Launch financial services on your platform) with a sub-context "Casos de uso" (Use cases). Body text explains the concept of becoming a financial services provider through platform integration, citing examples of companies like Shopify and Housecall Pro. It concludes with two call-to-action buttons: "Contacta con ventas" (Contact Sales) and "Empieza ahora" (Start now).
*   **Regional Website Notice:** An overlay message informing the user that they are viewing the Spanish website but appear to be in the United States, offering a link to "Switch to the United States site" and a button to close the notice.
*   **Client Showcase:** A list of company logos representing businesses that utilize Stripe's services, including Shopify, Housecall Pro, Lapay, Playmetrics, Gloss Genius, Squarespace, Shopmonkey, and Tekion.
*   **Cohesive Financial Services Section:** Introduced by "Diferencia tu plataforma" (Differentiate your platform), this section has the main heading "Crea servicios financieros cohesionados para tus clientes" (Create cohesive financial services for your clients). Body text describes how platforms can solve client financial challenges. This section details several core functionalities:
    *   **Accept Payments:** Describes how clients can accept online and in-person payments. An illustration shows a multi-step payment entry process ("SELECCIONAR ENTRADAS > INFORMACIÓN DE LA ENTRADA > INFORMACIÓN DEL PAGO") with options for "Tarjeta" (Card) and "Adeudo directo ACH" (Direct Debit ACH), culminating in a "PAGAR AHORA" (PAY NOW) button.
    *   **Access to Capital:** Explains how to provide financing programs. An illustration displays an offer selection with multiple loan amounts (e.g., "25.000 €") each detailing commission, interest rate, and repayment period. Data points like loan amount, commission, total amount owed, and repayment rate are presented.

        *   "Lancez-vous rapidement" (Launch quickly): Lists items like accepting online payments, configuring invoices, and simplifying tax calculation.

        *   "Simplifiez vos opérations" (Simplify your operations): Lists items like unifying reporting, automating processes, and simplifying workflows.

*   **Partner Specializations Section:**

**1. Page Overview**

The page's primary purpose is to inform potential users (platforms, creators) about how Stripe facilitates monetization, payment management, and platform operations for creators globally. It highlights various features and solutions designed to help creators earn income and platforms manage creator finances.

1. Page Overview:
A tutorial page about deploying a receipt parsing web application using Modal with React and FastAPI. The page provides instructions and code snippets.

2. Sections:
    *   Header: Includes links to Guide, Examples, Reference, and Playground. There is also a search input and links to Log In and Sign Up.
    *   Navigation: A list of links including: "Basic setup", "Define endpoints", "Running", and "Deploy".
    *   Main Content:
        *   Heading: "Serve a receipt parsing web app"
        *   Introductory Text: Describes the tutorial's purpose - to deploy a serverless React + FastAPI receipt parser application. Mentions an existing "Receipt Parser" app and links to another example.
        *   Image Placeholder: Illustrates the desired end result of the tutorial, displaying an example receipt and parsed text. Contains text "Receipt Parsing with GOT OCR 2.0" and a button labeled "Extract Text".
        *   Basic setup: Explains how to import necessary libraries and define the application. Contains code snippets using `pathlib`, `fastapi`, `fastapi.staticfiles`, and `modal`.
        *   Define endpoints: Describes the two endpoints needed: one to accept an image and submit it to a Modal job queue, and another to poll for results. Includes code snippets with decorators `@web_app.post("/parse")` and `@web_app.get("/result/{call_id}")`. Also contains code for parsing the image and handling function calls.
        *   Explanation: Describes how to specify dependencies using `modal.Image.debian_slim` and how to add static files for the frontend using `add_local_dir`.
        *   Explanation: Describes how to deploy the FastAPI app with Modal using decorators such as `modal.asgi_app` and `modal.concurrent`.
        *   Running: Explains how to run the app locally using the command `modal serve doc_ocr_webapp.py`.
        *   Image Placeholder: Shows expected output with receipt and parsed text
        *   Deploy: Explains how to deploy the application using the command `modal deploy doc_ocr_webapp.py`. Includes a link to additional documentation.
    *   Sidebar: Provides a section titled "Try this on Modal!" with instructions to create an account, install the Modal Python package, create an API token, and clone the modal-examples repository. It includes code snippets for these steps using shell commands.
    *   Footer: Contains the Modal logo, copyright information, links to About, Status, Changelog, Documentation, Slack Community, Pricing, Examples, and social media links.

    *   Header:
        *   Search Input: Accepts search queries.
        *   Links: "Log In", "Sign Up"

        *   Button: "Create account to run"
    *   Main Content:
        *   Image Placeholder: Contains a button labeled "Extract Text"

4. Content Details:
    *   Title: "Serve a receipt parsing web app"
    *   Tutorial description: "This tutorial shows you how to use Modal to deploy a fully serverless React + FastAPI application."
    *   Code snippets (Python):
        *   `from pathlib import Path`
        *   `import fastapi`
        *   `import fastapi.staticfiles`
        *   `import modal`
        *   `app = modal.App("example-doc-ocr-webapp")`
        *   `web_app = fastapi.FastAPI()`
        *   `@web_app.post("/parse")` ... (code for parse endpoint)
        *   `@web_app.get("/result/{call_id}")` ... (code for result endpoint)
        *   `image = modal.Image.debian_slim(python_version="3.12").uv_pip_install(...)`
        *   `local_assets_path = Path(_file__).parent / "doc_ocr_frontend"`
        *   `image = image.add_local_dir(local_assets_path, remote_path="/assets")`
        *   `@app.function(image=image)` ... (code for wrapper function)
    *   Code snippets (Shell):
        *   `$ pip install modal`
        *   `$ modal setup`
        *   `$ git clone https://github.com/modal-labs/modal-examples`
        *   `$ cd modal-examples`
        *   `$ modal serve 09_job_queues/doc_ocr_webapp.py`
    *   Command: `modal serve doc_ocr_webapp.py`
    *   Command: `modal deploy doc_ocr_webapp.py`
    *   Text: "Try it out for yourself here."
    *   Text: "Let's get the imports out of the way and define an App."
    *   Text: "Modal works with any ASGI or WSGI web framework. Here, we choose to use FastAPI."
    *   Text: "We need two endpoints: one to accept an image and submit it to the Modal job queue, and another to poll for the results of the job."
    *   Text: "In `parse`, we're going to submit tasks to the Function defined in the Job Queue tutorial, so we import it first using `Function.lookup`."
    *   Text: "We call `.spawn()` on the Function handle we imported above to kick off our Function without blocking on the results. `spawn` returns a unique ID for the function call, which we then use to poll for its result."
    *   Text: "/result uses the provided call_id to instantiate a modal.FunctionCall object, and attempt to get its result. If the call hasn't finished yet, we return a 202 status code, which indicates that the server is still working on the job."
    *   Text: "Now that we've defined our endpoints, we're ready to host them on Modal. First, we specify our dependencies - here, a basic Debian Linux environment with FastAPI installed."
    *   Text: "Then, we add the static files for our front-end. We've made a simple React app that hits the two endpoints defined above. To package these files with our app, we use `add_local_dir` with the local directory of the assets, and specify that we want them in the `/assets` directory inside our container (the `remote_path`). Then, we instruct FastAPI to serve this static file directory at our root path."
    *   Text: "We serve them from our FastAPI app as StaticFiles."
    *   Text: "To put our FastAPI app on Modal, we need to return it from a Python function that is wrapped with some extra decorators:"
    *   Text: "`modal.asgi_app` to ensure the Modal system knows to route web traffic to it (and in what format)"
    *   Text: "`modal.concurrent` to allow more than one request (e.g. for stylesheet and for HTML) to be served concurrently"
    *   Text: "`app.function` to turn our Python function into a Modal Function and define the infrastructure it needs (here, just the dependencies)."
    *   Text: "While developing, you can run this as an ephemeral app by executing the command"
    *   Text: "If successful, this will print a URL for your app that you can navigate to in your browser 🥂."
    *   Text: "Modal watches all the mounted files and updates the app if anything changes. See these docs for more details."
    *   Text: "To deploy your application, run"
    *   Text: "That's all!"

    *   Text in sidebar: "You can run this example on Modal in 60 seconds"
    *   Text in sidebar: "After creating a free account, install the Modal Python package, and create an API token."

1. Page Overview:
A documentation page explaining how to fine-tune a language model to replace a CEO using a Slack bot named DoppelBot, deployed on Modal.

    *   **Header:** Contains links to Guide, Examples, Reference, and Playground. Includes search input, and links to Log In and Sign Up.

    *   **Discussion Thread:** A series of messages from different users (akshat, erik APP, erik (real)) related to the DoppelBot, including replies and timestamps. Users can interact with messages using upvote/downvote.

    *   **How it Works:** Detailed description of the process behind DoppelBot. It mentions using the Slack SDK, Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA), and Modal Volumes. Contains links to clone the repo and set up a Slack token.
    *   **Scraping Slack:** Describes how the scraper fetches messages from Slack, including the message format. Includes an example command.
    *   **Fine-tuning:** Details about the fine-tuning process, including the choice of Llama 3.1, LoRA, and the use of torchtune. Includes a graph with "train/loss" as the title and "train/global_step" as the x-axis label.

    *   **Slack Bot:** Description of how the Slack bot is implemented, including the types of events handled and example code. It has a command to deploy the slackbot.
    *   **Multi-Workspace Support:** Explanation of how to support multiple Slack workspaces, including using OAuth and a serverless Postgres database (Neon). Includes a link to instructions for setting up Neon with Modal.
    *   **Next Steps:** A short congratulatory message and links to documentation and examples.
    *   **Footer:** Contains links to About, Status, Changelog, Documentation, Slack Community, Pricing, and Examples. Also, links to external profiles.

1. Page Overview: Documentation page explaining regional invocations for Edge Functions.

2. Sections:
    *   Page Navigation: Includes links to: Edge Functions, Overview, Quickstart (Dashboard), Quickstart (CLI), Development Environment, Architecture, Environment Variables, Managing Dependencies, Function Configuration, Error Handling, Routing, Deploy to Production, Local Debugging with DevTools, Testing your Functions, Logging, Troubleshooting, Regional Invocations, Status codes, Limits, Pricing, Supabase Auth, Supabase Database (Postgres), Supabase Storage.
    *   Main Content:
        *   Title: "Regional Invocations"
        *   Subtitle: "Execute Edge Functions in specific regions for optimal performance."
        *   Description: Explanation of how Edge Functions execute in the closest region by default, and the benefits of regional execution for intensive operations.
        *   List of operations benefiting from regional execution: Bulk database operations, File uploads, Complex queries with descriptions for each.
        *   "Available regions" Section: A list of supported regions grouped by continent. Includes the region code and location: Asia Pacific, North America, Europe, South America.
        *   "Usage" Section: Instructions on specifying the region programmatically using the Supabase Client library, or the x-region HTTP header. Includes code examples for Javascript and mentions cURL. Also explains the use of `forceFunctionRegion` query parameter. Includes a note about verifying the execution region by looking at `x-sb-edge-region` in Edge Function Logs.
        *   "Region runtime information" Section: Describes the `SB_REGION` environment variable.
        *   "Region outages" Section: Explains that requests will not be re-routed automatically when a region is explicitly specified.

3. Interactive Elements:
    *   Search input: "Search docs..."
    *   "Sign up" button.
    *   Like/Dislike buttons for "Is this helpful?" question.
    *   Tab selection for code examples: JavaScript and cURL.
    *   Link to "Edit this page on GitHub".
    *   Link to "Contact support".
    *   Link to "See Changelog".
    *   Link to "Check system status".
    *   Navigation links to other documentation pages.

4. Content Details:
    *   Title: Regional Invocations
    *   Subtitle: Execute Edge Functions in specific regions for optimal performance.
    *   Text: "Edge Functions automatically execute in the region closest to the user making the request. This reduces network latency and provides faster responses. However, if your function performs intensive database or storage operations, executing in the same region as your database often provides better performance."
    *   List Items:
        *   Bulk database operations: Adding or editing many records
        *   File uploads: Processing large files or multiple uploads
        *   Complex queries: Operations requiring multiple database round trips
    *   Available Regions: A list of available regions and their location.
    *   Code Example (JavaScript):
        *   import { createClient, FunctionRegion } from '@supabase/supabase-js'
        *   const { data, error} = await supabase.functions.invoke('function-name', {
        *   region: FunctionRegion.UsEast1, // Execute in us-east-1 region
        *   })
    *   Text: "In case you cannot add the x-region header to the request (e.g.: CORS requests, Webhooks), you can use forceFunctionRegion query parameter."
    *   Note: "You can verify the execution region by looking at the x-sb-edge-region HTTP header in the response. You can also find it as metadata in Edge Function Logs."
    *   Text: "Functions have access to the following environment variables: SB_REGION: The AWS region function was invoked"
    *   Text: "When you explicitly specify a region via the x-region header, requests will NOT be automatically re-routed to another region."
    *   Alert message: "Test your function's performance with and without regional specification to determine if the benefits outweigh automatic region selection."

## Functional Description of the Page

### 1. Page Overview

This page is a documentation or example page within the Modal Docs website. Its primary purpose is to provide a detailed, functional guide for building a full-stack application that uses MongoDB Atlas Vector Search and GeoJSON with Modal. It explains the setup, deployment, and interaction of backend and frontend components for a hybrid search engine.

### 2. Sections

**Global Header Section:**
*   **Site Identity:** A logo displaying "Modal Docs" which links to the documentation home page.
*   **Primary Navigation:** A set of links: "Guide", "Examples" (currently active, indicating the user is viewing an example), "Reference", "Playground".
*   **Utility Navigation:**
    *   A search input field, accompanied by a hint for a keyboard shortcut (K).
    *   A "Log in" link.
    *   A "Sign up" button.

**Page-Specific Navigation Section (Left Sidebar):**
*   A hierarchical list of example topics, serving as a table of contents for the "Examples" section of the documentation.
*   Topics are grouped under categories such as "Build a scalable AI coding platform", "Reinforcement Learning", "Embeddings", "Parallel processing and job scheduling", "Serve a Document OCR web app", "Training models from scratch", and "Hosting popular libraries".
*   Each item in the list is a link to a different example or documentation page.
*   The current page's topic, "Turn satellite images into vectors and store them in MongoDB," is highlighted as the active selection.

**Main Content Area:**

1.  **Introduction Section:**
    *   **Title:** "Using MongoDB Atlas Vector and GeoJSON Search with Modal".
    *   **Description:** Explains the application's core functionality as a hybrid search engine for satellite images, leveraging geospatial and temporal metadata, and pre-trained embeddings. Mentions the use of the European Space Agency's Sentinel satellites and the Clay foundation model.
    *   **Action Link:** A link inviting the user to "take your deployment of the application for a spin here."
    *   **Utility Button:** A "Copy page" button to copy the entire page content.

2.  **Overview Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Overview".
    *   **Summary Text:** Describes the core architecture involving MongoDB Atlas for metadata storage and Modal for compute orchestration, vector embeddings, and serving data.
    *   **Numbered List of Dataflow Steps:**
        1.  Retrieving satellite images from the European Space Agency's Sentinel satellites via a public STAC API.
        2.  Running a Modal job to query for metadata and store it in a MongoDB Atlas database.
        3.  Asynchronously running a Modal job to identify new images and compute their embeddings.
        4.  Hosting a database client on Modal for data manipulation and vector/geospatial search queries.
        5.  Running a static FastAPI server on Modal to execute queries and render results for a frontend.
    *   **Concluding Text:** Emphasizes that the entire application is built using Modal and MongoDB Atlas with minimal setup.

3.  **Deploying the Backend Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Deploying the Backend".
    *   **Setup: Modal and MongoDB Atlas Subsection:**
        *   **Heading:** "Setup: Modal and MongoDB Atlas".
        *   **Instructions:** Details prerequisites, including a Python environment, and provides a link to Modal setup instructions ("here"). Mentions Modal's free tier covers compute for the example.
        *   **MongoDB Atlas Account Instructions:** Explains the need for a MongoDB Atlas account, database creation (named `modal-examples`), database user setup, and creating a Modal Secret for connection information. Provides links ("all IP addresses" and "here") for dashboard navigation.
    *   **MongoDB Client (database.py) Subsection:**
        *   **Heading:** "MongoDB Client (database.py)".
        *   **Command Verification:** Provides a command to verify the Modal Secret and MongoDB Atlas instance setup: `modal run -m backend.database::MongoClient.ping`.
        *   **Data Manipulation Instructions:** Explains how to add an Area of Interest (AOI) to the database using a command: `modal run -m backend.database --action add_aoi`. Mentions that the default GeoJSON is from a GitHub repository (`geojsonio`) and allows specifying a different file.
        *   **Deployment Instructions:** Explains that `modal run` is for one-off tasks and `modal deploy` is for deploying webhooks, followed by the deployment command: `modal deploy -m backend.database`.
        *   **OpenAPI Docs Information:** Describes interactive OpenAPI documentation for webhooks, accessible via the Modal dashboard and a specific URL for the geographic search endpoint. Notes that search results won't appear until backfill jobs are executed.
    *   **Backfill and Updates (extract.py) Subsection:**
        *   **Heading:** "Backfill and Updates (extract.py)".
        *   **Data Population Instructions:** Explains how to add data by querying the Sentinel STAC API and provides the command to search for images: `modal run -m backend.extract`.
        *   **Result Verification:** Mentions checking results via Atlas UI or the search webhook.
        *   **Regular Update Deployment:** Provides the command to deploy the application for regular database updates: `modal deploy -m backend.extract`.
    *   **Clay Embeddings Service (embeddings.py) Subsection:**

## Functional Description of Supabase Documentation Page

### 1. Page Overview

This page is a documentation article for Supabase, specifically a "Framework Quickstart" guide titled "Use Supabase with SolidJS." Its primary purpose is to provide step-by-step instructions for developers to integrate Supabase services with a SolidJS application, covering project setup, client library installation, environment variable configuration, data querying, and application startup.

### 2. Sections

The page is structured with global navigation, local documentation navigation, a main content area for the tutorial, and a page footer.

**2.1. Global Header Navigation**
*   **Brand and Home Link:** A Supabase logo functions as a link to the main Supabase website.
*   **Documentation Indicator:** The text "DOCS" indicates the current context.
*   **Primary Navigation Links:** A set of top-level links for site navigation:
    *   "Start"
    *   "Products" (provides a dropdown menu of related product links)
    *   "Build" (provides a dropdown menu of related build links)
    *   "Manage" (provides a dropdown menu of related management links)
    *   "Reference" (provides a dropdown menu of related reference links)
    *   "Resources" (provides a dropdown menu of related resource links)

*   **Call-to-Action:** A "Sign up" button.
*   **Menu Toggle:** A menu icon to potentially reveal additional navigation options.

**2.2. Documentation Navigation Section (Sidebar)**
This section provides a hierarchical list of links for navigating within the Supabase documentation.
*   **Section: Start with Supabase**
    *   Link: "Start with Supabase" (currently active)
    *   Link: "Features"
    *   Link: "Architecture"
*   **Section: FRAMEWORK QUICKSTARTS**
    *   A list of links to quickstart guides for various frameworks, including: Next.js, React, Nuxt, Vue, Hono, Expo React Native, Flutter, iOS SwiftUI, Android Kotlin, SvelteKit, Flask (Python), Laravel PHP, Ruby on Rails, SolidJS (currently active), RedwoodJS, Refine.
*   **Section: WEB APP DEMOS**
    *   A list of links to web app demos for various frameworks, including: Next.js, React, Vue 3, Nuxt 3, Angular, RedwoodJS, SolidJS, Svelte, SvelteKit.

**2.3. Main Content Area**
This area contains the core tutorial content, presented as a series of numbered steps.
*   **Breadcrumbs:** A navigation path indicating the page's location within the documentation hierarchy: "Start with Supabase > Framework Quickstarts > SolidJS".
*   **Page Title:** "Use Supabase with SolidJS".
*   **Page Description:** "Learn how to create a Supabase project, add some sample data to your database, and query the data from a SolidJS app."

Each step includes instructional text and relevant code snippets.

*   **Step 1: Create a Supabase project**
    *   Instructional text directing the user to `database.new` to create a new project.
    *   Alternative instructions for creating a project using the Management API.
    *   A code block containing `curl` commands for obtaining an access token and creating a new project via API.
    *   Instructions for creating a table and inserting sample data using the Table Editor.
    *   Alternative instructions for using the SQL Editor to create an `instruments` table with sample data.
    *   A code block containing SQL commands to create the `instruments` table with `id` and `name` fields, and to insert 'violin', 'viola', and 'cello' as sample data.
    *   Instructions for making data publicly readable.
    *   A code block containing SQL commands to enable row-level security and create a policy allowing public read access to the `instruments` table.

*   **Step 2: Create a SolidJS app**
    *   Instructional text explaining how to create a SolidJS app using the `degit` command.
    *   A code block labeled "Terminal" containing an `npx` command to initialize a SolidJS project.

*   **Step 3: Install the Supabase client library**
    *   Instructional text introducing the `supabase-js` library.
    *   Instructions to navigate into the SolidJS app directory and install the `supabase-js` package.
    *   A code block labeled "Terminal" containing `cd` and `npm install` commands.

*   **Step 4: Declare Supabase Environment variables**
    *   Instructions to create a `.env.local` file and populate it with Supabase connection variables.
    *   A section for "Project URL" with a "No project found" indicator, a text input placeholder "YOUR PROJECT URL", and a "log in" link to retrieve the URL.
    *   A section for "Publishable key" with a "No project found" indicator, a text input placeholder "YOUR PUBLISHABLE KEY", and a "log in" link to retrieve the key.
    *   A section for "Anon key" with a "No project found" indicator, a text input placeholder "YOUR ANON KEY", and a "log in" link to retrieve the key.
    *   A code block labeled ".env.local" showing the format for environment variables: `VITE_SUPABASE_URL` and `VITE_SUPABASE_PUBLISHABLE_KEY`.
    *   An informational note titled "Changes to API keys" describing updates to API key management, distinguishing between legacy and new keys, and providing guidance on how to find and create them. It includes links to the "Connect dialog", "Settings page", "Legacy API Keys tab", and a "Create new API Keys" action.
    *   A link "Read the API keys docs" for further explanation.

*   **Step 5: Query data from the app**
    *   Instructions to create a Supabase client in `App.jsx` to fetch instruments data.
    *   Instructions to add a `getInstruments` function to fetch data and display the query result.
    *   A code block labeled "src/App.jsx" containing JavaScript code for creating a Supabase client, an asynchronous function `getInstruments` to query the 'instruments' table, and a SolidJS component `App` that uses `createResource` to display the fetched instrument names in an unordered list.

*   **Step 6: Start the app**
    *   Instructions to start the app and navigate to `http://localhost:3000` to view the list of instruments.
    *   A code block labeled "Terminal" containing the `npm run dev` command.

1. Page Overview: Documentation page explaining how to optimize cold start performance in Modal.

2. Sections:
    *   Header: Contains links to "Guide," "Examples," "Reference," and "Playground." Also contains a search input field, a link to "Log In", and a link to "Sign Up".
    *   Navigation: A list of links to different documentation topics, including "Networking", "Tunnels", "Proxies (beta)", "Cluster networking", "Data sharing and storage", "Passing local data", "Volumes", "Storing model weights", "Cloud bucket mounts", "Dicts", "Queues", "Dataset Ingestion", "Performance", "Cold start performance", "Memory Snapshot", "Geographic latency", "Reliability and robustness", "Failures and retries", "Preemption", "Timeouts", "GPU health", "Troubleshooting", "Security and privacy", "Integrations", "Using OIDC to authenticate with external services", "Connecting Modal to your Datadog account", and "Connection Modal to your OpenTelemetry".
    *   Main Content: Contains the main documentation about cold start performance, divided into multiple sections.
        *   "Cold start performance" - Introductory text explaining cold starts and their impact on latency.
        *   "Reduce time spent queueing for warm containers" - Explains how new containers are booted and how to reduce the time spent queueing.
        *   "Warm up containers faster" - Explains how Modal optimizes container boot time and provides tips for further optimization.
        *   "Run more warm containers" - Discusses the option of running more warm containers and mentions parameters like `scaledown_window`, `min_containers`, and `buffer_containers`.
        *   "Keep containers warm for longer with scaledown_window" - Explains how to configure the `scaledown_window` parameter. Includes example code using the `modal` library.
        *   "Overprovision resources with min_containers and buffer_containers" - Explains how to use the `min_containers` and `buffer_containers` parameters. Includes example code using the `modal` library.
        *   "Reduce latency from initialization" - Explains how initialization work affects latency.
        *   "Move initialization work out of the first invocation" - Suggests moving initialization logic to the global scope or a container enter method. Contains a link to a guide on how to use enter with machine learning model weights.
        *   "Share initialization work across cold starts with memory snapshots" - Explains how memory snapshots can improve cold start performance. Contains a link to the memory snapshot guide.
        *   "Optimize initialization code" - Introduction to optimizing code.
        *   "Load multiple large files concurrently" - Provides an example of loading multiple Huggingface transformer models concurrently using `ThreadPoolExecutor`. Includes example code.
    *   Footer: Contains links to "About", "Status", "Changelog", "Documentation", "Slack Community", "Pricing", and "Examples". Also contains social media links.

3. Interactive Elements:
    *   Search input field: Allows users to search the documentation.

    *   "Copy page" button: Copies the content of the current page to the clipboard.
    *   Links in the navigation: Navigate to different documentation topics.
    *   Links within the text: Link to related documentation or external resources, for example: containers, target queueing time for optimization, target initialization for optimization, enter, this guide, memory snapshot.

4. Content Details:

    *   Section Titles: "Reduce time spent queueing for warm containers", "Warm up containers faster", "Run more warm containers", "Keep containers warm for longer with scaledown_window", "Overprovision resources with min_containers and buffer_containers", "Reduce latency from initialization", "Move initialization work out of the first invocation", "Share initialization work across cold starts with memory snapshots", "Optimize initialization code", "Load multiple large files concurrently"

1.  **Page Overview:** Documentation page describing how to configure Okta Single Sign-On (SSO) with Modal.

2.  **Sections:**

    *   **Okta SSO:** Page title.
    *   **Prerequisites:** A list of requirements:
        *   A Workspace on an Enterprise plan.
        *   Admin access to the Workspace.
        *   Admin privileges for Okta Organization.
    *   **Supported features:** A list of SSO features:
        *   IdP-initiated SSO
        *   SP-initiated SSO
        *   Just-In-Time account provisioning
        A link to the Okta Glossary for more information.
    *   **Configuration:** Introductory text describing that enabling "Require SSO" will force all users to sign in via Okta.
    *   **Configuration steps:** A numbered list detailing the steps to configure Okta SSO:
        *   Step 1: Add Modal app to Okta Applications:
            1.  Sign in to your Okta admin dashboard.
            2.  Navigate to the Applications tab and click "Browse App Catalog". Contains a screenshot of the "Browse App Integration Catalog" interface with a search field populated with "modal" and a list of applications.
            3.  Select "Modal" and click "Done."
            4.  Select the "Sign On" tab and click "Edit." Contains a screenshot of the "Settings" section with tabs: General, Sign On, Import, Assignments.
            5.  Fill out Workspace field to configure your specific Modal workspace. Text describing the Workspace field. Includes a reference to "Step 2".
        *   Step 2: Link your Workspace to Okta Modal application
            1.  Navigate to your application on the Okta Admin page.
            2.  Copy the Metadata URL from the Okta Admin Console. Contains a screenshot of the "SAML Settings" showing a Single Sign On URL.
            3.  Sign in to https://modal.com and visit your Workspace Management page's Identity and Provisioning tab.
            4.  Paste the Metadata URL in the input and click "Save Changes".
        *   Step 3: Assign users / groups and test the integration
            1.  Navigate back to your Okta application on the Okta Admin dashboard.
            2.  Click on the "Assignments" tab and add the appropriate people or groups. Contains a screenshot of the "Assignments" section with tabs: General, Sign On, Import, Assignments. It has dropdowns to assign and convert assignments, as well as search functionality.
            3.  To test the integration, sign in as one of the users you assigned in the previous step.
            4.  Click on the Modal application on the Okta Dashboard to initiate Single Sign-On.

        1.  Enter your workspace name in the input.
        2.  Click "continue with SSO" to authenticate with Okta.

    *   **Secondary Navigation:** A list of links to other documentation pages: Geographic latency, Reliability and robustness, Failures and retries, Preemption, Timeouts, GPU health, Troubleshooting, Security and privacy, Integrations, Using OIDC to authenticate with external services, Connecting Modal to your Datadog account, Connecting Modal to your OpenTelemetry provider, Okta SSO, Slack notifications (beta), Workspace & account settings, Workspaces, Environments, Modal user account setup, Service users, Billing, Other topics, JavaScript/Go SDKs, Modal 1.0 migration guide, File and project structure, Developing and debugging, Developing Modal code with LLMs.

Its primary purpose is to introduce and explain "AgentFS," a copy-on-write overlay filesystem, demonstrating its functionality and providing details on its implementation across different operating systems.

    *   Includes a prominent conceptual image representing "AgentFS with overlay filesystem."
*   **Article Introduction:**
    *   Comprises several paragraphs that define AgentFS, explain its core benefit (providing isolation, auditability, reproducibility, and portability for agents), and introduce the `agentfs run` command as a mechanism to manage agent filesystems with copy-on-write overlay support.
    *   Mentions that the filesystem operates within a "sandbox."
*   **"Example: Agentic coding with AgentFS" Section:**
    *   A heading indicating an example walkthrough.
    *   Introductory text setting up a scenario for using AgentFS with coding agents.
    *   A code block showing a `git clone` command and its output.

    *   Text explaining the isolation of agent actions.

    *   Text asserting that the host filesystem remains unchanged.
    *   A code block showing `git status` output, confirming no changes on the host.
    *   Text describing how to join an existing AgentFS session.
    *   A code block showing the retrieval of a session ID via `echo $AGENTFS_SESSION`.
    *   Text explaining how to use the session ID to view changes from another shell.
    *   A code block showing `agentfs run` with a session ID and `bash`, and the resulting `git status` output indicating changes within the session.
    *   Concluding text about controlling the session ID.
*   **"How does it work?" Section:**
    *   A heading for a functional explanation.
    *   Descriptive text outlining the two key components of the `agentfs run` command: a "copy-on-write overlay filesystem" and a "sandbox."
*   **"Copy-on-write overlay" Section:**
    *   A heading focusing on the technical mechanism.
    *   Detailed explanation of the overlay filesystem's two layers (a read-only base and a writable delta layer), describing how file reads, writes, and deletions are handled.
*   **"Linux with FUSE and namespaces" Section:**
    *   A heading for platform-specific implementation details.
    *   Text explaining AgentFS's implementation on Linux using FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) and kernel features like `user namespaces`, `unshare()`, and bind-mounts.
    *   Lists specific paths that remain writable: `~/.local`, `~/.npm`, `/proc`, `/sys`, `/dev`, and `/tmp`.

    *   Text explaining AgentFS's implementation on macOS using NFS (Network File System) and the `sandbox-exec` utility for sandboxing.
    *   Mentions `macFUSE` and `/sbin/mount_nfs` in the context of previous approaches and current methods.
    *   Refers to a `Sandbox profile` and `~/.local` as a writable path.
*   **"Putting it together" Section:**
    *   A heading to summarize the overall process.
    *   Text providing a concise summary of how AgentFS creates and manages sessions, sets up the overlay filesystem, and sandboxes the agent.

## Functional Description of the ModalDocs "Volumes" Page

### 1. Page Overview

This page is a documentation article within the ModalDocs platform, focused on providing comprehensive information about "Volumes" – a high-performance distributed file system feature for Modal applications. Its primary purpose is to educate users on how to create, manage, and utilize Volumes, including specific details about "Volumes v2" and advanced use cases.

### 2. Sections

The page is structured into several main areas:

**A. Global Header Section:**
*   **Site Navigation:** Contains links for navigating the broader documentation site: "Docs", "Guide", "Examples", "Reference", and "Playground".
*   **Search Functionality:** An input field labeled "Search" to find content across the documentation, with a keyboard shortcut indicator "⌘K".
*   **User Account Actions:** Links for "Log In" and "Sign Up" to manage user accounts.

**B. Primary Navigation Section (Document Tree):**
*   A hierarchical list of documentation categories and articles.
*   Categories include: "Scheduling and cron jobs", "Web endpoints", "Streaming endpoints", "Request timeouts", "Proxy Auth Tokens", "Networking", "Data sharing and storage", "Performance", "Cold start performance", "Memory Snapshot", "Reliability and robustness".
*   Each category contains a list of specific articles.
*   The "Volumes" article, which is the current page, is highlighted within the "Data sharing and storage" category.
*   Sub-articles related to Volumes are also listed: "Storing model weights", "Cloud bucket mounts", "Dicts", "Queues", "Dataset ingestion".

**C. Main Document Content Section:**
This section presents the detailed article content about "Volumes", organized by headings and subheadings.

*   **Article Title and Actions:**
    *   Main heading: "Volumes".
    *   A "Copy page" button, which likely copies the URL of the current page.
*   **Introduction to Volumes:** Text describing Modal Volumes as a high-performance distributed file system, its benefits for various application types, and a general introduction.
    *   Contains internal links to specific documentation pages: "this page" (likely for `modal.Volume` object reference) and "this page" (likely for `modal.Volume` class reference).
*   **Volumes v2:**
    *   Heading: "Volumes v2".
    *   Text introducing Volumes v2 as a new generation file system in beta preview.
    *   A specific annotation indicating instructions relevant to V2.
    *   A link "Read more about Volumes v2 below" to a later section on the same page.
*   **Creating a Volume:**
    *   Heading: "Creating a Volume".
    *   Text explaining how to create a Volume using the `modal volume create CLI` command.
    *   A code example demonstrating the `modal volume create my-volume` command and its output.
    *   An annotation indicating how to specify `version-2` when creating a Volume.
*   **Using a Volume on Modal:**
    *   Heading: "Using a Volume on Modal".
    *   Text explaining how to attach an existing Volume to a Modal Function using `volume.from_name`.
    *   A code example demonstrating attaching a Volume, writing data to it, and committing changes within a Python function.
    *   Text about browsing and manipulating Volumes via an ad hoc Modal Shell.
    *   A code example demonstrating the `modal shell --volume my-volume --volume another-volume` command.
    *   Text about where Volumes are mounted and their performance characteristics (bandwidth).
*   **Downloading a file from a Volume:**
    *   Heading: "Downloading a file from a Volume".
    *   Text describing file size limits for frontend downloads and recommending CLI for larger files.
    *   A code example demonstrating the `modal get my-volume xyz.txt xyz-local.txt` command.
*   **Creating Volumes lazily from code:**
    *   Heading: "Creating Volumes lazily from code".
    *   Text explaining how to create Volumes lazily using `create_if_missing=True`.
    *   A code example demonstrating `modal.Volume.from_name('my-volume', create_if_missing=True)`.
    *   An annotation indicating how to specify `version-2` for lazy creation.
    *   Text explaining the effect of lazy creation.
*   **Using a Volume from outside of Modal:**
    *   Heading: "Using a Volume from outside of Modal".
    *   Text stating that Volumes can be used via Python SDK or CLI.
    *   **Using a Volume from local code:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text about interacting using the Python client library.
        *   A code example demonstrating `batch_upload` using a Volume object.
        *   A link "reference documentation" for more details.
    *   **Using a Volume via the command line:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text about interacting using the command line interface and how to list subcommands.
        *   A code example showing `modal volume` usage and its subcommand options (`-help`, `cp`, `get`, `ls`, `put`, `rm`, `create`, `delete`, `list`).
        *   A note for users of `modal.NetworkFileSystem`.
        *   A link "reference documentation" for more details.
*   **Volume commits and reloads:**
    *   Heading: "Volume commits and reloads".
    *   Text explaining the explicit commit/reload mechanism of Modal's filesystem, contrasting it with normal filesystems. Details `reload()` and `commit()` methods and `background commits`.
    *   Text describing the state of an attached Volume at container creation time and subsequent modifications.
    *   A code example demonstrating the effect of `reload()` using two Python functions (`f` and `g`) and their interaction with a Volume.
    *   Text showing the expected output of the code example.
    *   Text explaining the execution flow of the example.
*   **Background commits:**
    *   Heading: "Background commits".
    *   Text explaining that Modal Volumes perform background commits automatically during function execution and container shutdown.
    *   Text highlighting the benefit for training or fine-tuning ML models.
*   **Model serving:**
    *   Heading: "Model serving".
    *   Text explaining how a single ML model can be served by baking it into a `modal.Image` or by using a `modal.Volume` for decoupling image builds from model storage.
    *   Text describing using Volumes for serving a large number of models efficiently.
    *   A code example demonstrating the basic structure for model serving using a Volume.
    *   A link "our guide to storing model weights on Modal" for further details.
*   **Model checkpointing:**
    *   Heading: "Model checkpointing".
    *   Text defining checkpoints as snapshots of an ML model, configurable via callback functions of ML frameworks, useful for managing preemption.
    *   A link "our example code for long-running training" for further examples.
    *   **Hugging Face transformers:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text explaining how to periodically checkpoint into a `modal.Volume` by setting the `Trainer`'s `output_dir`.
        *   A code example demonstrating checkpointing a Hugging Face model to a Volume.
*   **Volume performance:**
    *   Heading: "Volume performance".
    *   Text describing optimal performance for Volumes with less than 50,000 files/directories and latency scaling.
    *   Text stating a hard limit of 500,000 nodes (files, directories, symbolic links) per Volume, with an error message `EXDEV: No space left on device` for exceeding this limit.
    *   Text recommending consideration of Volumes v2 for large numbers of files, with a link "below" to a later section.
*   **Filesystem consistency:**
    *   Heading: "Filesystem consistency".
    *   **Concurrent modification:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text describing support for concurrent modification from multiple containers, with a warning about last-write-wins semantics and potential data loss.
        *   Text outlining limitations on concurrent commits (number and duration) and the recommendation to avoid more than 5.
        *   Text concluding that Volumes are not ideal for use cases requiring distributed file locking.
*   **Busy Volume errors:**
    *   Heading: "Busy Volume errors".
    *   Text explaining that reloading a Volume with open files will result in a "Volume busy" error.
    *   A code example demonstrating a `volume.reload()` call failing when a file is open.
*   **Can't find file on Volume errors:**
    *   Heading: "Can't find file on Volume errors".
    *   Text advising to prepend the mounted path when accessing files in a Volume.
    *   A code example illustrating writing to a file in a mounted Volume and the consequence of accessing it without the correct path.
*   **Volumes v2 overview:**
    *   Heading: "Volumes v2 overview".
    *   Text comparing Volumes v2 to v1, noting behavioral similarities but significant implementation differences, and outlining key differences.
    *   **Volumes v2 is still in beta:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text stating its beta status, warning against mission-critical use, and suggesting it's suitable for non-precious data.
    *   **Volumes v2 are HIPAA compliant:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text stating that data deletion is HIPAA compliant.
    *   **Volumes v2 is more scaleable:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text highlighting support for more files, higher throughput, irregular access patterns, and faster commits/reloads.
        *   Text noting support for hard-linking.
    *   **In v2, you can store as many files as you want:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text stating no limit on the number of files in Volumes v2, contrasting with the v1 limit of 500,000.
    *   **In v2, you can concurrently from hundreds of containers:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text stating no performance degradation for concurrent writes from many containers, contrasting with v1's recommendation of no more than five concurrent writers and last-write-wins semantics.
    *   **In v2, random accesses have improved performance:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text describing how v2 improves performance for random writes by removing overhead compared to v1.
    *   **Volumes v2 has a few limits in place:**
        *   Subheading.
        *   Text listing artificial limits for v2 during its development:
            *   Files must be less than 1 TiB.
            *   At most 32,768 files can be stored in a single directory; total file count is unbounded.
            *   Traversing the filesystem can be slower due to on-demand loading of the filesystem tree.
*   **Upgrading v1 Volumes:**
    *   Heading: "Upgrading v1 Volumes".
    *   Text describing the current lack of automated upgrade tools and the manual migration process (creating a new v2 Volume and copying files).
    *   Text providing a warning about deleting v1 Volumes, stating that dependent apps will cease to function.
    *   Text advising on how to reuse the name of an existing v1 Volume.
    *   A code example demonstrating manual migration using `cp` or `rsync` commands within a Modal debug shell.
*   **Further examples:**
    *   Heading: "Further examples".
    *   A list of links to other documentation examples:
        *   "Character LoRA fine-tuning with model storage on a Volume".
        *   "Protein folding with model weights and output files stored on Volumes".
        *   "Dataset visualization with Datasette using a SQLite database on a Volume".

**1. Page Overview:**

It also provides links to external platforms via icons (GitHub, Discord, a social media platform represented by an 'X' icon), a "Login" link, and a "Get Started" call-to-action button.

*   **Release Overview Section:** Features a graphical element with the text "TURSO RELEASE." This section introduces the release with the text "Turso v0.4.0 is now released with the following changes:" followed by a bulleted list of key features:
    *   Concurrent write with MVCC improvements
    *   Partial sync support and more sync SDKs
    *   Page cache spilling
    *   SDK improvements
    *   ANALYZE + Query performance
    *   Hash joins
    It also includes links to view the full changelog and getting started instructions.
*   **Detailed Feature Description - Concurrent Writes with MVCC:** This section provides an in-depth explanation of the "Concurrent writes with MVCC" feature. It describes the feature's purpose, its experimental status, implications for database operation, and includes code examples demonstrating `PRAGMA journal_mode` usage for `experimental_mvcc` and `wal` modes. An example of an error message when opening an incompatible SQLite file is also presented.
*   **Detailed Feature Description - Partial Sync and More Sync SDKs:** This section details the "Partial sync" feature, explaining its functionality for improving application responsiveness and its "bootstrap strategy" for data synchronization. It also mentions a prefetch strategy and the availability of sync SDKs in Python, JavaScript, and Go, with a link to further documentation.
*   **Detailed Feature Description - Other Notable Improvements:** This section lists additional enhancements, including:
    *   Python SDK offering an `aiosqlite`-compatible asynchronous API.
    *   Support for configuring page cache size via `PRAGMA cache_size = n` for large queries.
    *   Improved support for `ANALYZE` and `ANALYZE [table]` commands for query optimization.
    *   Enhanced join performance through a new disk-based ephemeral B-tree algorithm.

**4. Content Details:**

*   **Header Text:** "Modal", "GPU Glossary", "Terminal", "Light green", "Light", "Search", "⌘K", "Deploy on GPUs".
*   **Table of Contents Headings:** "TABLE OF CONTENTS".
*   **Table of Contents Items:** "Home", "README", "Device Hardware", "CUDA (Device Architecture)", "Streaming Multiprocessor SM", "Core", "Special Function Unit SFU", "Load/Store Unit LSU", "Warp Scheduler", "CUDA Core", "Tensor Core", "Tensor Memory Accelerator TMA", "Streaming Multiprocessor Architecture", "Texture Processing Cluster TPC", "Graphics/GPU Processing Cluster GPC", "Register File", "L1 Data Cache", "Tensor Memory", "GPU RAM", "Device Software", "CUDA (Programming Model)", "Streaming Assembler SASS", "Parallel Thread Execution PTX", "Compute Capability", "Thread", "Warp", "Cooperative Thread Array", "Kernel".
*   **Main Content Path:** `/device-software/kernel`.
*   **Main Content Heading:** "What is a CUDA Kernel?".
*   **Diagram Labels:** "CUDA thread", "CUDA thread block", "Shared Memory", "CUDA kernel grid", "Global Memory", "CUDA Core", "Streaming Multiprocessor", "L1 Data Cache", "GPU", "GPU RAM".
*   **Explanatory Text (excerpt):** "A kernel is the unit of CUDA code that programmers typically write and compose, akin to a procedure or function in languages targeting CPUs. Unlike procedures, a kernel is called (\"launched\") once and returns once, but is executed many times, once each by a number of threads. These executions are generally concurrent (their execution order is non-deterministic) and parallel (they occur simultaneously on different execution units). The collection of all threads executing a kernel is organized as a kernel grid - aka a thread block grid, the highest level of the CUDA programming model's thread hierarchy. A kernel grid executes across multiple Streaming Multiprocessors (SMs) and so operates at the scale of the entire GPU. The matching level of the memory hierarchy is the global memory. In CUDA C++, kernels are passed pointers to global memory on the device when they are invoked by the host and return nothing -- they just mutate memory. To give a flavor for CUDA kernel programming, let's walk through two implementations of the \"hello world\" of CUDA kernels: matrix multiplication of two square matrices, A and B. The two implementations will differ in how they map the textbook matrix multiplication algorithm onto the thread hierarchy and memory hierarchy. In the simplest implementation, inspired by the first matmul kernel in Programming Massively Parallel Processors ↗ (4th edition, Figure 3.11), each thread does all of the work to compute one element of the output matrix -- loading in turn each element of a particular row of A and a particular column of B into registers, multiplying the paired elements, summing the results, and placing the sum back in global memory."

1.  **Page Overview:** This page is an interactive LLM Engine Advisor, allowing users to explore the throughput and latency characteristics of different LLM engine configurations.

2.  **Sections:**
    *   **Header:** Contains links labeled "Advisor", "Executive Summary", and "How to Benchmark". Also contains a link to Modal and a link to something that expresses "I'm feeling curious".
    *   **LLM Engine Advisor:** This section contains input fields to configure the benchmark parameters.
    *   **Interactive Chart:** Presents a chart displaying latency versus throughput for various LLM engine configurations based on the user-specified parameters.
    *   **Frequently Asked Questions:** Presents a list of questions and answers about the benchmark and its methodology.
    *   **Configuration Display:** Presents a text-based configuration based on a selected data point in the chart.
    *   **Footer:** Displays a version number and an acknowledgement.

3.  **Interactive Elements:**
    *   **Dropdown Menus:**
        *   "I want to serve": Allows selecting an LLM model. Example value is "Llama 3.1 8B".
        *   "with": Allows selecting an inference engine. Example value is "any engine".
        *   "Clients should receive the first token in": Allows specifying which token should be returned. Example value is "the first token".
        *   "under": Allows specifying a target latency in seconds. Example value is "1 second".
        *   "95% of the time": Allows specifying the percentage of time latency target should be met.
        *   "I expect on average": Allows specifying the expected number of input/output tokens. Example value is "128 tokens in / 1024 tokens out".
        *   "I want to see": Allows filtering the configurations to display. Example value is "every benchmarked configuration".
        *   "Metric": Allows selecting the metric shown. Example value is "Time To First Token".
        *   "Aggregate": Allows selecting the aggregate. Example value is "p95".
    *   **Chart:** Interacting with a point on the chart highlights a corresponding configuration.
    *   **Link:** "this page" within the "What is this? How do I use it?" section links to a page about the methodology.
    *   **Link:** "our executive summary" within the "What is this? How do I use it?" section links to a high-level overview of the results.
    *   **Link:** "Click the dice" allows a selection of a random result.
    *   **Link:** "our executive summary" within the "Should I use VLLM, SGLang, or TensorRT-LLM?" section links to a high-level overview of the results.
    *   **Link:** "contact us" within the "Why is the minimum time-to-first-token (TTFT) around 200 ms, even for small models?" section.
    *   **Link:** "CPU-centric benchmarking work from Spare Cores" within the "I want to run language models on CPUs/TPUs/LPUs. Do you have results for that?" section.
    *   **Link:** "here" within the "I want to know all the details about how you ran these benchmarks so that I can poke holes in your results. Where can I find them?" section.
    *   **Link:** "our open repository of configs for this benchmark" within the "I want to know all the details about how you ran these benchmarks so that I can poke holes in your results. Where can I find them?" section.
    *   **Link:** "here" within the "You can find a detailed walkthrough of our general approach to benchmarking LLM engines here." section.
    *   **Copy Button:** Copies the configuration text to the clipboard.

4.  **Content Details:**
    *   **Headings:** "LLM Engine Advisor", "Frequently Asked Questions".
    *   **Chart Labels:** "Latency (s, p95 Time To First Token) - Lower is better", "Throughput (requests/s per replica) - Higher is better".
    *   **FAQ Questions:** "What is this? How do I use it?", "Should I use VLLM, SGLang, or TensorRT-LLM?", "What do I do if my LLM engine needs to serve hundreds of requests per second? I only see loads ranging from under one RPS to a few dozen.", "Why is the minimum time-to-first-token (TTFT) around 200 ms, even for small models?", "I want to run language models on CPUs/TPUs/LPUs. Do you have results for that?", "What data did you use?", "I want to know all the details about how you ran these benchmarks so that I can poke holes in your results. Where can I find them?"
    *   **Chart Legend:** "sglang, 1 x H100", "vllm, 1 x H100", "tensorrt-llm, 1 x H100".
    *   **Configuration display:** Shows configuration details like "SGLANG_VERSION", "ENV_VARS", "CLI_ARGS", "MAX_THROUGHPUT", "GPU", "MODEL_REPO", "MODEL_CACHE_PATH", "MINUTES", "HOURS".
    *   **Footer:** "20 25" and an acknowledgement to multiple people.

1. Page Overview: This is a landing page for Modal, a platform for machine learning model training. The primary purpose is to showcase Modal's training capabilities and encourage users to sign up and start building.
