    *   Header: Contains the company logo "Modal", a navigation menu with links to "Product", "Solutions", "Resources", "Customers", "Pricing", and "Docs". Also contains buttons to "Log In" and "Sign Up".
    *   Hero Section: Contains the heading "Modal Training: Train more, configure less", a brief description "Launch more experiments and training jobs. Spin up single-node experiments or scale to multi-node GPU training instantly." and two call-to-action buttons: "Get Started" and "Read the docs".
    *   Testimonials Section: Includes two customer testimonials. One from substack, with a quote, the customer's name, and title. Another one from ramp, with a quote, the customer's name, and title.
    *   Key Features Section: Contains the title "Where researchers can run experiments, not ops", followed by descriptions of three features: "Define in code" with associated text describing the ability to define a training function with Modal's SDK, "Native storage" with a description of ingesting training data from any source, and "Sub-second startup" with a description of launching GPUs in less than 1 second.
    *   Multi-Node Training Section: Contains the title "Speed up training jobs by going multi-node", followed by three bullet points describing the benefits of multi-node training, "Scale from 1 GPU to 64 with just one line of code", "Spin up a cluster in a second with no minimum commitments", and "B200, H200, and H100 clusters equipped with Infiniband and private networking". Includes a chart titled "NanoGPT Training Duration" showing training duration over different numbers of GPUs.
    *   Training Control Section: Contains the title "No black boxes. You control the training logic", followed by three sections each describing the usage of "Any base model", "Any training framework", and "Any MLOps framework"
    *   "Built with Modal" Section: Contains the title "Built with Modal" followed by a series of sections, each showcasing a use case built with Modal. Each has a title describing the example, a short description, and a link icon.
    *   End-to-End ML Lifecycle Section: Contains the title "Your end-to-end ML lifecycle in one place" and a paragraph "Seamlessly integrate data pre-processing, training, and serving.", followed by a list of ML components: "Inference", "Training", "Sandboxes", "Batch", "Notebooks" and "Core Platform".
    *   Footer Call to Action Section: Contains the title "Ship your first app in minutes.", a call to action button "Get Started" and text "$30/month free compute".
    *   Footer Navigation Section: Contains a list of "Products" with links to "Modal Inference", "Modal Sandboxes", "Modal Training", "Modal Notebooks", "Modal Batch", and "Modal Core Platform". Also contains a list of "Resources" with links to "Documentation", "Pricing", "Stock Community", "Articles", "GPU Glossary", "LLM Engine Advisor", and "Model Library". A list of "Popular Examples" is also present with links such as "Serve your own LLM API" and "Create custom art of your pet". Finally, a list of "Company" links is present with "About", "Blog", "Careers", "Events", "Privacy Policy", "Security & Privacy", and "Terms".
    *   Social Media and Legal Section: Contains social media icons for X, LinkedIn, and other platforms. Also contains copyright information.

3. Interactive Elements:
    *   "Get Started" button: Likely leads to a sign-up or account creation page.
    *   "Read the docs" button: Leads to the documentation page.
    *   Navigation menu links: Lead to their respective pages (Product, Solutions, Resources, Customers, Pricing, Docs).
    *   "Log In" button: Leads to a login page.
    *   "Sign Up" button: Leads to a registration page.
    *   Links to example projects: Lead to a detailed view or code repository for each example.
    *   Social media icons: Link to the company's social media profiles.
    *   Product, Resources, Popular Examples, and Company links: Each link navigates to the corresponding page.

4. Content Details:
    *   Main Headline: "Train more, configure less"
    *   Subheadline: "Launch more experiments and training jobs. Spin up single-node experiments or scale to multi-node GPU training instantly."
    *   Testimonials: Quotes from customers about their experience with Modal.
    *   Feature descriptions: Text explaining the benefits of defining training in code, native storage, and sub-second startup times.
    *   Multi-node training details: Information about scaling to multiple GPUs and cluster configurations.
    *   Training control details: Information about different model frameworks.
    *   Example project titles: Descriptive titles for each showcased project.
    *   Lifecycle components: "Inference", "Training", "Sandboxes", "Batch", "Notebooks" and "Core Platform".
    *   Footer call to action: "Ship your first app in minutes." and "$30/month free compute".

**1. Page Overview:**
This page is a detailed product listing for an AI model, specifically "Qwen3-30B-A3B" by Alibaba Cloud, within the Vercel ecosystem. Its primary purpose is to provide information about the model, demonstrate its usage through a code example and an interactive playground, list its associated providers and pricing, and present other related models from the same vendor.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Header Navigation:**
    *   Contains a site logo linking to the Vercel homepage.
    *   A set of primary navigation links: "Products", "Resources", "Solutions", "Enterprise", and "Pricing". "Products", "Resources", and "Solutions" indicate they have sub-navigation options.
    *   User action links: "Log In", "Contact", and "Sign Up".

*   **Model Information Section:**
    *   A breadcrumb navigation provides links to "All Models" and "Alibaba Cloud Models".
    *   The model's name is displayed: "Qwen3-30B-A3B".
    *   An identifier for the model, `alibaba/qwen-3-30b`, is presented with a button to copy it to the clipboard.
    *   A descriptive text block details the model: "Qwen3 is the latest generation of large language models in Qwen series, offering a comprehensive suite of dense and mixture-of-experts (MoE) models. Built upon extensive pre-training, Qwen3 delivers groundbreaking advancements in reasoning, instruction-following, agent capabilities, and multilingual support."

*   **Code Example Section:**
    *   A tab labeled `index.ts` is present.
    *   A code snippet is displayed, demonstrating how to use the model with a `streamText` function. The snippet includes `import { streamText } from 'ai'`, `const result = streamText({`, `model: 'alibaba/qwen-3-30b',`, and `prompt: 'Why is the sky blue?',` within a function call.
    *   A button allows copying the code snippet.

*   **Playground Section:**
    *   A heading identifies this area as "Playground".
    *   An introductory text explains usage and billing: "Try out Qwen3-30B-A3B by Alibaba Cloud. Usage is billed to your team at API rates. Free users get $5 of credits every 30 days, and you are considered a free user if you haven't made a payment."
    *   An interactive chat interface is provided, labeled "Qwen3-30B-A3B".
        *   It includes a button to expand the interface.
        *   A text input field with the placeholder "Ask a question..."
        *   Buttons for additional actions: one for adding content (plus icon), and one for attaching files (envelope icon).
        *   A send message button (paper plane icon).
        *   Text: "Chat with Qwen3-30B-A3B".
        *   A link indicating "Powered by AI Gateway".

*   **Providers Section:**
    *   A heading identifies this area as "Providers".
    *   A descriptive text explains the AI Gateway's role and provider preferences, including a link to "documentation". The text also states that by using a provider, the user acknowledges and agrees to its terms.
    *   A table lists provider details.
        *   Table headers include: "Provider", "Context", "Max Output", "Input", "Output", "Cache", "Image Gen", "Web Search".
        *   One provider, "DeepInfra", is listed with its logo. It includes links to "Legal: Terms" and "Privacy".
        *   Interactive buttons are available for copying provider information.
        *   Specific data points are provided: Context: 41K, Max Output: 16K, Input: $0.08/M, Output: $0.29/M. Other data fields show no information.

*   **More Models by Alibaba Cloud Section:**
    *   A heading identifies this section: "More models by Alibaba Cloud".
    *   A table lists additional models from the same vendor.
        *   Table headers are: "Model", "Context", "Max Output", "Input", "Output", "Cache", "Image Gen", "Web Search".
        *   Each entry includes a model name (e.g., `alibaba/qwen-3-14b`, `alibaba/qwen-3-235b`, `alibaba/qwen3-coder`, etc.).
        *   Each model entry has interactive buttons for copying and additional information.
        *   Numerical data is provided for Context, Max Output, Input, and Output for each model. Some models also show "Read:" and "Write:" pricing. The "Cache", "Image Gen", and "Web Search" columns have no data for these models.

*   **Footer Navigation:**
    *   An interactive button to return to the top of the page.
    *   Copyright information: "© 2024 Vercel Inc. All rights reserved."
    *   Four distinct lists of links grouped under headings:
        *   "Products": AI, Enterprise, Fluid Compute, Next.js, Observability, Previews, Rendering, Security, Turbo, Domains, Sandbox, v0 (external link).
        *   "Resources": Community (external link), Docs, Knowledge Base, Academy, Help, Integrations, Platforms, Pricing, Resources, Solution Partners, Startups, Templates, SDKs by Vercel (with sub-options).
        *   "Company": About, Blog, Careers, Changelog, Contact Us, Customers, Events, Partners, Shipped, Privacy Policy, Legal (with sub-options).
        *   "Social": GitHub, LinkedIn, Twitter, YouTube.
    *   A "Loading status..." indicator.
    *   Interactive buttons for selecting the interface theme (system, light, dark mode).

**1. Page Overview:**
This is a blog post page, serving to inform readers about a specific technical topic: "Faster interpreters in Go: Catching up with C++." Its primary purpose is to present detailed technical content, provide navigation to other parts of the website, and offer related calls to action.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Global Notification Banner:**
    *   Contains a promotional message: "PlanetScale Metal Postgres databases are here."
    *   Includes a call-to-action link: "Learn more", which leads to further information about Postgres databases.

*   **Header Navigation:**
    *   A site logo/brand name ("PlanetScale") which functions as a link to the homepage.
    *   A set of primary navigation links: "Platform", "Resources", "Documentation", "Pricing", "Contact".
    *   User-related navigation links: "Log In" and "Get started".
    *   A call-to-action button: "Book a meeting".

*   **Article Information Section:**

    *   The article's main title: "Faster interpreters in Go: Catching up with C++".
    *   Author information: "By Vicent Marti".
    *   Publication date: "March 20, 2025".

*   **Article Content Section:**
    *   Contains the full body of the blog post, structured with paragraphs of text.
    *   Includes embedded links within the text that point to relevant external resources or other pages.
    *   Presents code snippets within distinct content areas.
    *   Divides the content with several sub-headings, indicating different topics discussed in the article:
        *   "What's a SQL evaluation engine?"
        *   "The shapes of an interpreter"
        *   "An efficient Virtual Machine in Go"
        *   "Almost statically typed"
        *   "Evalengine performance in Vitess over time"
        *   "Conclusion"
        *   "Recent results compared with MySQL"
        *   "Addendum: So why not JIT?"

*   **Ancillary Content Section:**
    *   **Table of Contents:** A list of links corresponding to the main sub-headings within the article. Clicking these links navigates the user to the respective section within the current page.
    *   **Promotional Area:** Contains a message promoting a product: "PlanetScale Postgres is the fastest way to run Postgres in the cloud. Plans start at just $5 per month."
    *   **Promotional Call-to-action:** A link labeled "Learn more" within the promotional area, likely leading to product details or pricing for Postgres.
    *   **RSS Feed Link:** A link to "Get the RSS feed" for blog updates.

*   **Footer Section:**
    *   A collection of organizational links, categorized for clarity:
        *   **Company:** "About", "Blog", "Changelog", "Careers", "Events".
        *   **Product:** "Case studies", "Enterprise", "Pricing".
        *   **Resources:** "Documentation", "Support", "Status", "Trust Center".
        *   **Courses:** "Database Scaling", "Learn Vitess", "MySQL for Developers".
        *   **Open source:** "Vitess", "Vitess community", "GitHub".
    *   A set of legal and policy links: "Privacy", "Terms", "Cookies", "Patents", "Do Not Share My Personal Information".
    *   Copyright information: "© 2026 PlanetScale, Inc. All rights reserved."
    *   A set of links to external social media or development platforms: "GitHub", "LinkedIn", "YouTube", "Facebook".

**3. Interactive Elements:**

*   **Navigation Links:** All text links in the header and footer, as well as the table of contents links, are interactive and navigate to other pages or sections of the current page.
*   **Buttons:** The "Book a meeting" element in the header is an interactive button designed to initiate a scheduling process.
*   **Embedded Links:** Text within the article body that appears as a link (e.g., "SQL evaluation engine", "open-source database", "PlanetScale", "vtgate", "MySQL", "test suite", "this issue in the Insert SQL function", "this bug when searching substrings", "Efficient Interpretation using Quickening", "mailing list post from 2011", "continuation-style evaluation loops", "this report from 2021", "actual implementation in Vitess") allows users to access additional related information.

**4. Content Details:**
The page presents a detailed technical explanation of how interpreters work in Go, comparing their performance and implementation approaches with C++. It covers concepts like SQL evaluation engines, AST-based interpreters, virtual machines, bytecode, JIT compilation, and specific examples using Vitess and MySQL. It references specific technical design choices and discusses performance implications. Promotional content highlights the PlanetScale Postgres product.

1. Page Overview:

**1. Page Overview:**
This is a pricing page for Modal, a serverless compute platform. Its primary purpose is to inform potential users about the various pricing plans, detailed compute costs, available credit programs, and feature comparisons to help them choose a suitable plan or understand the cost structure.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Header Navigation:**
    *   A company logo for "Modal".
    *   Primary navigation links: "Product", "Solutions", "Resources".
    *   Secondary navigation/user links: "Customers", "Pricing", "Docs", "Log In".
    *   A "Sign Up" call-to-action button.

*   **Hero Section:**
    *   A heading: "Pricing as magical as our product".
    *   Descriptive text explaining Modal's pay-as-you-use pricing model, focusing on actual compute time rather than idle resources.
    *   Two calls-to-action: "Get Started" and "Contact Us".

*   **Pricing Plans Overview Section:**
    *   A sub-heading: "PRICING PLANS".
    *   Three distinct plan sections:
        *   **Starter Plan:**
            *   Indicates a base price of "$0 + compute / month".
            *   Description: Targets small teams and independent developers.
            *   A call-to-action button: "Get started with $30 / month free credit".
            *   A list of included benefits: "$30 / month free credits", "3 workspace seats included", "100 containers + 10 GPU concurrency", "Crons and web endpoints (limited)", "Real-time metrics and logs", "Region selection".
        *   **Team Plan:**
            *   Indicates a base price of "$250 + compute / month".
            *   Description: Targets startups and larger organizations scaling quickly.
            *   A call-to-action button: "Sign in to upgrade".
            *   A list of included benefits: "$100 / month free credits", "Unlimited seats", "1000 containers + 50 GPU concurrency", "Unlimited crons and web endpoints", "Custom domains", "Static IP proxy", "Deployment rollbacks".
        *   **Enterprise Plan:**
            *   Indicates "Custom" pricing.
            *   Description: Targets organizations prioritizing security, support, and long-term confidence.
            *   A call-to-action button: "Get in touch".
            *   A list of included benefits: "Volume-based discounts", "Unlimited seats", "Higher GPU concurrency", "Embedded ML engineering services", "Support via private Slack", "Audit logs, Okta SSO, and HIPAA".

*   **Detailed Compute Costs Section:**
    *   A heading: "Compute costs".
    *   A toggle control to switch between "Per hour" and "Per second" pricing display (currently showing "Per second").
    *   A list of GPU Tasks with their respective costs per second (e.g., Nvidia B200: $0.001736 / sec).
    *   CPU pricing: Physical core (2 vCPU equivalent) with its cost per core per second, including a minimum usage note.
    *   Memory pricing: Cost per GiB per second.

*   **Credit Grant Programs Section:**
    *   Three separate program descriptions:
        *   **Credit grants for startups:** Offers up to $25K free compute credits for early-stage startups with an "Apply Now" button.
        *   **Credit grants for academics:** Offers up to $10K free compute credits for graduate students, labs, and researchers with an "Apply now" button.
        *   **Use committed spend on Modal:** Provides information for users with existing committed spend on major cloud providers (AWS, Azure, GCP, OCI) to potentially use it on Modal, with a "Get In Touch" button.

*   **Modal Sandbox + Notebooks Pricing Section:**
    *   A heading: "Modal Sandbox + Notebooks Pricing".
    *   Descriptive text noting that GPU pricing follows standard rates, and CPU cycle is the billing basis.
    *   A toggle control to switch between "Per hour" and "Per second" pricing display (currently showing "Per second").
    *   CPU pricing: Physical core (2 vCPU equivalent) with its cost per core per second, including a minimum usage note.
    *   Memory pricing: Cost per GiB per second.

*   **Why Serverless? Section:**
    *   A heading: "Why serverless?".
    *   A sub-heading: "Serverless pricing vs. traditional cloud pricing".
    *   Descriptive text explaining serverless autoscaling benefits for spiky or unpredictable workloads.
    *   A comparison of pricing examples between "Traditional cloud" and "Modal serverless cloud", detailing estimated costs and contributing factors.

*   **Feature Comparison Table Section:**
    *   A heading: "Compare features".
    *   A comprehensive table comparing features and limits across "Starter", "Team", and "Enterprise" plans.
    *   Categories of features include: "Workspace", "Credits and variable costs", "Features", and "Security".
    *   Each category lists specific items (e.g., "Number of seats", "Cron jobs", "SOC 2 compliance") with corresponding details, availability indicators (checkmarks for available, crosses for not available), or values for each plan. A "Coming Soon" label is present for some features.

*   **Frequently Asked Questions Section:**

    *   A list of expandable questions, each with a toggle button to reveal or hide the answer (e.g., "How does serverless pricing differ from traditional on-demand pricing?").

*   **Final Call-to-Action Section:**

    *   Descriptive text: "$30 / month free compute".

*   **Footer:**

    *   A list of "Products" links (e.g., "Modal Inference", "Modal Notebooks").
    *   A list of "Resources" links (e.g., "Documentation", "Slack Community", "Pricing").

*   **Buttons:**

*   **Toggle Controls:** Two instances of "Per hour" / "Per second" toggle buttons to change the unit of cost display for compute resources.
*   **Expandable FAQ Items:** Each question in the "Frequently asked questions" section has a toggle to show or hide its answer.
*   **Social Media Links:** Links to Modal's profiles on X, LinkedIn, Hashnode, GitHub, and YouTube.

**4. Content Details:**

*   **Headings:** "Pricing as magical as our product", "PRICING PLANS", "Compute costs", "Credit grants for startups", "Credit grants for academics", "Use committed spend on Modal", "Modal Sandbox + Notebooks Pricing", "Why serverless?", "Serverless pricing vs. traditional cloud pricing", "Compare features", "Frequently asked questions", "Ship your first app in minutes.".
*   **Body Text:** Descriptions for Modal's pricing philosophy, plan features, credit programs, and serverless benefits.

1. Page Overview: This is a blog post detailing how Vercel improves website search engine ranking by optimizing Core Web Vitals.

2. Sections:
    *   **Article Header:** Contains the title "How Vercel improves your website's search engine ranking" and the subtitle "Strategies to optimize your Core Web Vitals."
    *   **Introduction:** Explains how Google Search ranks websites, mentioning relevance, quality, usability, and context.
    *   **The Core Web Vitals and their related metrics:** Defines the Core Web Vitals (LCP, FID, and CLS) and provides a table that describes these metrics, along with TTP, TTFB, FCP, and TBT.
    *   **Network response: Time to first byte (TTFB):** Explains TTFB and how it relates to optimizing content delivery.
    *   **Rendering: First Contentful Paint (FCP) and Largest Contentful Paint (LCP):** Describes FCP and LCP and ways to optimize LCP, like making content static.
    *   **Load complete: Time to Interactive (TTI) and Total Blocking Time (TBT):** Defines TTI and TBT and how to optimize them by only loading necessary content.
    *   **Responsiveness: First Input Delay (FID) and Interaction to Next Paint (INP):** Describes FID and INP and how to optimize INP by staying off the main thread.
    *   **Usability: Cumulative Layout Shift (CLS):** Defines CLS and its impact on user experience, including ways to optimize CLS, and Vercal's tools.
    *   **Takeaways:** A bulleted list summarizing the key points of the article with a call-to-action to deploy application on Vercel.

3. Interactive Elements:
    *   Links: There are links throughout the article to various resources, including Google Search Console Insights, PageSpeed Insights, Next.js documentation, and other related articles.
    *   Call-to-action: A link to deploy an application on Vercel.

4. Content Details:
    *   Heading: How Vercel improves your website's search engine ranking
    *   Subtitle: Strategies to optimize your Core Web Vitals
    *   Date Published: Mar 29, 2024
    *   Core Web Vitals Metrics Table:
        *   Metric: FCP, SI, LCP, TTI, TBT, CLS
        *   Description of Each Metric
        *   Good Threshold Value for Each Metric
    *   Takeaways: A list with various performance points.
        *   LCP measures perceived loading speed
        *   FID measures interactivity
        *   CLS measures visual stability
        *   Deploying your application on Vercel's managed Cloud vitals will automatically optimize your application's TTFB.
        *   Vercel's Edge Middleware handles CLS and many feature flags.
    *   Final link: Let's see how to improve.

        *   A table lists basic settings with their descriptions and default values:
            *   default_pool_size: "How many server connections to allow per user/database pair. Default: 20"
            *   min_pool_size: "Add more server connections to pool if below this number. Improves behavior when main server restarts after recovery. Default: 0"
            *   max_client_conn: "Maximum number of client connections allowed. Default: 60"
            *   sretry_delay: "The pgbouncer will close unused server connections that have been connected longer than this. 0 means close once than once/client. Default: 3600 seconds."
            *   server_idle_timeout: "Close server connections idle longer than this many seconds. Disables this timeout. Default: 600 seconds."
    *   Advanced settings:

            *   Connection limits
                *   max_prepared_statements: "When user runs PgBouncer tracks protocol level named prepared statements in transaction and statement pooling mode. Default: 100."
                *   max_db_connections: "Do not allow more than this many server connections per database regardless of users. 0 is unlimited. Default: 0."
                *   max_user_connections: "Do not allow more than this many server connections per user regardless of databases. 0 is unlimited. Default: 0."
            *   Timeouts
                *   query_timeout: "Cancel queries running longer than this. Use with smaller server_idle_timeout, primarily for network problems. Default: 0 seconds."
                *   query_wait_timeout: "Maximum time queries wait for execution. Client disconnects if query not assigned to server in time. 0 disables. Default: 120 seconds."
                *   client_idle_timeout: "Disconnect clients that are idle longer than this. This should be larger than client-side timeouts settings. Default: 0 seconds."
            *   Server health
                *   server_check_query: "Simple query to check if server connection is alive. Empty string disables sanity checking. Default: select 1."
            *   Logging
                *   log_connections: "Log successful logins. Default: 1 (enabled)."
                *   log_disconnections: "Log disconnections with reason. Default: 1 (enabled)."
                *   log_pooler_errors: "Log error messages the pooler sends to clients. Default: 1 (enabled)."
            *   Parameter handling
                *   ignore_startup_parameters: "Allow additional startup parameters that PgBouncer normally rejects. Specify here to PgBouncer allows users-handed them. Default: extra_float_digits"
            *   Low-Level Performance
                *   pkt_buf: "Internal buffer size for packets. Affects TCP packet size and memory usage. No need to set larger for stateless packets. Default: 4096 bytes."

4. Content Details:
    *   "PgBouncer provides connection pooling for your Postgres database."
    *   "PgBouncer is generally recommended for OLTP workloads. All application connections should be routed through PgBouncer whenever possible. Learn more about the pros and cons of the different connection methods on the connections overview page."
    *   "PlanetScale provides several options for using PgBouncer, including local PgBouncers and dedicated replica PgBouncers."
    *   "PgBouncer connections operate in transaction mode, which means pooled server connections are assigned to client connections on a per-transaction level. This provides excellent performance for OLTP workloads but limits certain PostgreSQL features that require persistent connections. Learn more at the PgBouncer documentation."
    *   "For use cases that require long-running operations, direct connections on port 5432 are recommended. For example:"
    *   The code snippet in "Local PgBouncer" starts with "psql 'host=xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx-1.psdb.cloud port=5432 user=...'"
    *   "The local PgBouncer does not support running queries to replicas; all connections through the local PgBouncer are automatically routed to the primary database, regardless of the username specification. Use a dedicated replica PgBouncer for replica access."
    *   "Dedicated replica PgBouncers can be created to run on nodes separate from the Postgres servers. This is useful for applications that send significant read traffic to replicas and need connection pooling. This offers similar high-availability benefits as the local PgBouncer but is used for read-only replica traffic."
    *   The code snippet in "Connecting to dedicated replica PgBouncers" starts with "psql 'host=xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx-1.replica.psdb.cloud port=5432 user=user_1234567890@xxxxxxxx'"
    *   The code snippet in "Connecting to dedicated primary PgBouncers" starts with "psql 'host=xxxxxxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxx-xxxxxxxxxxxx-1.psdb.cloud port=5432 user=user_1234567890@xxxxxxxx'"
    *   The table of basic settings contains parameters such as "default_pool_size", "min_pool_size", "max_client_conn", etc., along with their descriptions and default values.
    *   The table of advanced settings contains parameters such as "max_prepared_statements", "max_db_connections", "query_timeout", etc., along with their descriptions and default values.
    *   "Connection reuse is the key mechanism that makes PgBouncer effective. When a client completes a transaction, PgBouncer returns the server connection to the pool rather than closing it. The next client transaction can immediately reuse that existing connection without incurring the overhead of spawning a new Postgres process."
    *   The list of pooling modes includes "Session Pooling", "Statement Pooling", and "Transaction Pooling".
    *   "PgBouncer's transaction pooling mode provides excellent performance for OLTP workloads but limits certain PostgreSQL features that require persistent connections."
    *   "Using PgBouncer provides improved availability during configuration changes. When modifying Postgres Parameters, some changes require the server to be restarted. When these restarts happen, any direct connections to Postgres will be terminated. However, when using PgBouncer, client connections are maintained and PgBouncer handles reconnecting to Postgres after it restarts."
    *   "PgBouncer itself is a lightweight process, but high connection counts or high query throughput can overwhelm it's extent to capacity. PlanetScale offers multiple PgBouncer sizes to handle different workload demands."
    *   "PgBouncer has custom error messages that may be encountered in addition to standard Postgres errors."
    *   "Get help from the PlanetScale Support team, or join our Github discussion board to see how others are using PlanetScale."

Its primary purpose is to provide step-by-step instructions and contextual information.

1. Page Overview:
This is a documentation page for a database insights tool, providing information about query insights, including how to use them to identify performance issues and optimize database performance.

2. Sections:
*   Header: Contains product logo, navigation links to Platform, Vitess, Postgres, API Reference, CLI Reference, a search field, and links for "Log in" and "Get Started".
*   Sidebar Navigation: Contains a navigation list with links to Platform, Getting Started, Imports, Connecting, Schema changes, Monitoring, Query Insights, Anomalies, Schema recommendations, Powerboost, Integrations, Database auditing, Backups, Sharding, Vectordb, Metal, Security, Enterprise, and Troubleshooting.
*   Main Content Area:
    *   Title: "Query Insights" with descriptive text stating that "PlanetScale Insights gives you a detailed look at all active queries running against your database."
    *   Overview: Introductory paragraph explaining the tool's purpose: identifying queries that are too often, too long, producing errors, and using a graph to detect when a query was impacted. Includes a link to a list of all queries performed on the database.
    *   Insights page overview: Describes how to view insights for a database from the PlanetScale dashboard, including a conditional statement about requesting access. Includes a selector for choosing servers to analyze and an image depicting query insights.
    *   Queries overview table: Description of what the table shows (all queries performed on your database). Includes a link to understand how to read and interpret data in this section.
    *   Insights graph tabs: Description of the insights graph tabs available, including links to Query latency, Queries, and Rows written tabs.
    *   Query latency: Description of what the query latency tab displays.
    *   Queries: Description of what the queries tab displays.
    *   Rows read: Description of what the rows read tab displays.
    *   Rows written: Description of what the rows written tab displays.
    *   Errors: Description of what the errors tab displays.
    *   Queries overview: Description of the Queries overview in a table format including a link to complete query collection.
    *   Available query statistics: List of customizable metrics that appear on the options dropdown. Each item describes a statistic, for example: Query - The query that was run.
    *   Query filtering: Explains how to filter queries by selecting columns in the View Queries list.
    *   Query deep dive: Description about opening a query to view in the Queries list, along with actions that can be performed, like viewing a query explain plan and linking to a web console to access the query.
    *   Additional query information: Description of the available information regarding the query patterns and time series graphs.
    *   Notable queries: Explanation of what constitutes a notable query as one with a SQL comment or one producing an error.
    *   Complete query collection: Information about enabling the complete query collection for raw query data.
    *   Complete query collection and prepared statements: Informs users of issues that could arise from using prepared statements and disabling query collection.
    *   Need help?: Prompt to get help from the PlanetScale Support team.
*   Footer:
    *   Section asking if the page was helpful with a "Yes" and "No" button.
    *   Link to "Online DDL change unique keys".
    *   Navigation to previous and next pages.
    *   Set of social media and other links.

3. Interactive Elements:
*   Search field in header for searching content.
*   Sidebar navigation links to navigate to other documentation pages.
*   Links to other documentation pages throughout the main content.
*   Server Selector: A dropdown menu to choose the server for analysis.
*   "Yes" and "No" buttons in the footer for providing feedback on the page's helpfulness.

4. Content Details:
*   Heading: "Query Insights"
*   Descriptive text: "PlanetScale Insights gives you a detailed look at all active queries running against your database."
*   Section Headings: Overview, Insights page overview, Queries overview table, Insights graph tabs, Query latency, Queries, Rows read, Rows written, Errors, Queries overview, Available query statistics, Query filtering, Query deep dive, Additional query information, Notable queries, Complete query collection, Complete query collection and prepared statements, Need help?
*   List of metrics in the "Available query statistics" section.
*   Text content explaining various features and functionalities of the query insights tool.

1. Page Overview:
This page is an informational article about OAuth 2.1, detailing changes, deprecations, and migration guidance.

2. Sections:
*   Header: Contains navigation links labeled "Products," "Developers," "Resources," "Pricing," and "Sign In."
*   Article Title: The title of the article is "OAuth 2.1: What's new, what's gone, and how to migrate securely". It is followed by a descriptive paragraph explaining the article's content regarding changes in OAuth 2.1, including removal of implicit flow, mandatory PKCE, modern refresh token strategies, security upgrades and migration checklist. Displays author information (name and date).
*   "TL;DR" Section: Provides a summarized overview of OAuth2.1 changes.
*   "Why OAuth 2.1?" Section: Explains reasons for OAuth 2.1 update. It includes a list of reasons OAuth 2.1 is being updated. The listed reasons include: key security improvements from multiple RFCs, deprecates legacy or unsafe flows, provides clearer guidance to developers and implementers. It also includes a set of links related to OAuth 2.0: OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice (BCP), OAuth 2.0 for Browser-Based Apps, Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE), OAuth 2.0 for Native Apps.
*   "What's new (and what's gone)" Section: Describes updates in OAuth 2.1 including: PKCE is now mandatory, Implicit flow is removed, Refresh tokens for SPAs (securely), Bearer tokens remain - but use them carefully, Redirect URIs: No more wildcards, and Password grant is deprecated. Some items include descriptions and explanations with diagrams.
*   "OAuth 2.0 vs OAuth 2.1" Section: It provides a table comparing features between OAuth 2.0 and OAuth 2.1. Features compared include: Spec Status, PKCE Requirement, Implicit Flow, Password Grant (ROPC), Refresh Tokens for Public Clients, Redirect URI Matching, Access Tokens, Token Storage (HTTPS), Token Replay Protection, Recently Recommendations, Client Authentication Secrets.
*   "Implementation guidance" Section: Outlines implementation recommendations for modern app types including Browser-based apps, Mobile/native apps, Server-side apps, Public clients.
*   "Migration checklist" Section: Presents a checklist of tasks to perform when migrating. Checklist items: Implement PKCE for all clients (public and confidential), Generate and validate code_challenge / code_verifier, Require and validate code_verifier on token request, Remove usage of code_challenge_method=plain... unless truly unavoidable (e.g. Legacy), Use short-lived authorization codes and tokens, Validate exact redirect_uri - Watch on every authorization request, Eliminate use of the Implicit Flow ( response_type=token ), Deprecate Resource Owner Password Credentials (ROPC) grant, Securely store access/refresh tokens, Implement Refresh Token Rotation (RTRO) for SPAs, Detect reuse of old refresh tokens, Invalidate tokens on replay, Narrow token scopes to least privilege needed, Optionally explore sender-constrained tokens (mTLS or DPoP) for highly sensitive APIs.
*   "What's not changing?" Section: Explains what remains the same.
*   "When will OAuth 2.1 be final?" Section: Informs about the status of OAuth 2.1.
*   "How WorkOS can help" Section: Explains how WorkOS can help with OAuth 2.1 transition.
*   Page Footer: A section containing links regarding products, compliance, developers, resources and company. There are also social media links.

3. Interactive Elements:
*   Header navigation links: "Products," "Developers," "Resources," "Pricing," and "Sign In."
*   Within the "Why OAuth 2.1?" section, links to: OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice (BCP), OAuth 2.0 for Browser-Based Apps, Proof Key for Code Exchange (PKCE), OAuth 2.0 for Native Apps.

4. Content Details:
*   Article Title: "OAuth 2.1: What's new, what's gone, and how to migrate securely"
*   Article description: Explains that article covers changes to OAuth 2.1, including removal of implicit flow, mandatory PKCE, and modern refresh token strategies. It guides through the security upgrades and offers a clear migration checklist.
*   TL;DR summary of OAuth2.1: OAuth2.1 is a cleanup and consolidation - not a revolution, but (officially) deprecates legacy from liberalized grants, mandates PKCE everywhere, and lays down a cleaner, more secure path for building modern apps.
*   Reasons for OAuth 2.1 update:
    *   Consolidates key security improvements from multiple RFCs.
    *   Deprecates legacy or unsafe flows.
    *   Provides clearer guidance to developers and implementers.
*   List of new or deprecated items in OAuth 2.1:
    *   PKCE is now mandatory
    *   Implicit Flow is removed
    *   Refresh tokens for SPAs (securely)
    *   Bearer tokens remain – but use them carefully
    *   Redirect URIs: No more wildcards
    *   Password grant is deprecated
*   Table data comparing OAuth 2.0 and OAuth 2.1 features, containing corresponding values for each version.
*   Migration checklist containing a numbered list of steps.
*   Text describing the current status of OAuth 2.1 development.
*   Text explaining how WorkOS can assist with the OAuth 2.1 transition, highlighting its support for Authorization Code + PKCE, exact redirect URI enforcement, and secure token storage patterns.

## Functional Description of Web Page

### 1. Page Overview
This is a documentation page providing instructions on how to integrate and configure Prometheus with PlanetScale to monitor database branches. Its primary purpose is to guide users through the technical steps required for this setup.

### 2. Sections

**Global Header Area:**
*   **Brand Identifier:** A logo and the company name "PlanetScale".
*   **Main Product Navigation:** A set of links to different product areas: "Platform", "Vitess" (currently active), "Postgres", "API Reference", and "CLI Reference".
*   **Search Functionality:** An input field labeled "Search..." for finding content within the documentation.
*   **Assistance Feature:** A button labeled "Ask AI".
*   **Account Management:** A "Log in" button.
*   **User Onboarding/Trial:** A "Get started" button.
*   **Sales/Contact:** A "Book a meeting" button.
*   **Settings Access:** An icon representing user or application settings.
*   **Page Utility:** A "Copy page" button with a dropdown indicator for additional options.

**Main Navigation Sidebar:**
*   **General Links:** A list of links including "Blog", "Contact Us", "Status", and "Benchmarks".
*   **Documentation Categories:** A hierarchical list of documentation categories.
    *   **Top-level Category:** "Vitess".
    *   **Top-level Category:** "Platform", which is expanded to reveal sub-categories.
        *   **Sub-categories:** "Getting Started", "Imports", "Connecting", "Schema changes", and "Integrations".
        *   **Expanded Sub-category:** "Monitoring", which reveals further related topics.
            *   **Specific Topics:** "PlanetScale Insights", "Prometheus" (parent of current page), "Connecting Prometheus" (currently active page), "Visualizing in Grafana", "Collecting in the Datadog Agent", "Forwarding metrics to New Relic", and "Metrics List".
        *   **Additional Sub-categories:** "Database auditing", "Backups", "Scaling", "Sharding", "Vectors", "Metal", "Security", and "Enterprise".

**Main Content Area:**
*   **Breadcrumbs:** A link to "Prometheus", indicating the current content's context.
*   **Primary Page Heading:** "Prometheus".
*   **Introduction:** Text explaining PlanetScale's Prometheus-compatible metrics endpoints, API-driven service discovery, and the use of the HTTP SD protocol for automatic information gathering.
*   **Prequisites Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Prequisites".
    *   **Text:** States assumptions about Prometheus 3.x instance and local machine operation. Discusses deployment for managed Prometheus services and mentions the lack of `remote_write` support.
*   **Getting Started Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Getting Started".
    *   **Instructions:** Details on provisioning a PlanetScale Service token and granting "read_metrics_endpoints" permissions.
    *   **Example Interface:** An image displaying an "Organization access permissions" dialog. This dialog includes an access permission search input, a list of checkboxes with permission names (e.g., "read_organization", "read_invoices", "read_databases", "read_metrics_endpoints") and corresponding descriptions. The dialog contains "Save permissions" and "Cancel" buttons.
*   **Configuring Prometheus Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Configuring Prometheus".
    *   **Instructions:** Guidance on adding a scrape configuration for a Prometheus instance.
    *   **Code Example:** A code block showing a YAML configuration snippet for `scrape_configs`, specifying `job_name`, `http_sd_configs` with `url`, `authorization` details, and `refresh_interval`. This block includes utility icons for copying, viewing raw content, and editing.
    *   **Instructions:** Details on saving the configuration to `prometheus.yml`.
*   **Start Prometheus Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Start Prometheus".
    *   **Instructions:** How to run Prometheus using the configuration file.
    *   **Command Example:** A command line code block displaying `promotheus --config.file=prometheus.yml`.
    *   **Information:** Specifies the default Prometheus listen address and a local access URL (`http://127.0.0.1:9090`).
*   **Validating Service Discovery Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Validating Service Discovery".
    *   **Instructions:** Steps to verify Prometheus is collecting branches by visiting a Prometheus service-discovery interface.
    *   **Interface Example:** An image displaying a Prometheus "Discovered labels" interface, showing `instance` and `job` labels.
    *   **Command Example:** A code block showing a `pscale` CLI command to list branches (`pscale branch list test --org nick`).
    *   **Data Table:** A code block representing tabular data with columns: "NAME", "ID", "PARENT BRANCH", "REGION", "PRODUCTION", "SAFE MIGRATIONS", and two data rows.
    *   **Interface Example:** An image displaying a Prometheus "Targets" interface, showing two endpoints with associated labels, last scrape time, and state (UP).
*   **Querying Prometheus Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Querying Prometheus".
    *   **Instructions:** Guidance on querying metrics using a specific Prometheus query (`planetescal_vtgate_total_pods{planetescal_database_branch_id="7wuxewx4l6p"}`) and references a "metrics reference guide".
    *   **Graph Settings:** Suggests setting the graph to "stacked".
    *   **Graph Example:** An image displaying a Prometheus graph interface. It includes a query input field, an "Execute" button, data visualization tabs (Table, Graph, Explain), a time range selector, and a stacked bar chart showing `planetescal_vtgate_total_pods` over time with a legend.
*   **Next Steps Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Next Steps".
    *   **Information:** Mentions Prometheus refreshes the branch list every 10 minutes and collects metrics every 30 seconds.
    *   **Related Resources:** A list of links to further documentation: "Metrics reference", "Grafana and Prometheus" tutorial, and "Sending metrics to New Relic" tutorial.
*   **Need help? Section:**
    *   **Heading:** "Need help?".
    *   **Support Information:** Text directing users to the "PlanetScale Support team" and a "GitHub discussion board" for assistance.
    *   **Feedback Mechanism:** A question "Was this page helpful?" with "Yes" and "No" buttons for user feedback.

**On-Page Navigation Section:**

**Page Navigation Links (Bottom):**

*   **Next Page:** A link to "Grafana Dashboard for PlanetScale Branches".

**Footer Area:**
*   **Social Media Links:** A set of icons linking to Twitter, GitHub, LinkedIn, and Facebook.

*   **Search Input:** Allows users to input text to search for content.

*   **Checkboxes:** Within the "Organization access permissions" dialog, allow users to select or deselect specific permissions.
*   **Code Block Utilities:** Icons associated with code blocks enable copying code, viewing raw content, or editing.

### 4. Content Details
*   **Headings:** Clearly delineates sections such as "Prometheus", "Prequisites", "Getting Started", "Configuring Prometheus", "Start Prometheus", "Validating Service Discovery", "Querying Prometheus", "Next Steps", and "Need help?".
*   **Instructional Text:** Provides step-by-step guidance for setting up and using Prometheus with PlanetScale.

This is a detailed documentation or guide page from WorkOS, intended for developers. Its primary purpose is to explain the architecture, evolution, and implementation of authentication and authorization (MCP auth) for multi-client platform (MCP) servers, including how WorkOS can be utilized for these processes.

### 1. Page Overview
This page serves as a comprehensive developer's guide to "MCP auth," detailing various aspects of authentication and authorization for multi-client platforms, with a focus on OAuth 2.1, PKCE, JWT validation, and role-based access control (RBAC). It explains core concepts, provides implementation guidance, and illustrates how WorkOS features integrate.

### 2. Sections

**A. Header Navigation**
*   **Company Identifier**: A WorkOS logo.
*   **Primary Navigation Links**: A set of links to main product areas: "Products," "Developers," "Resources," and "Pricing."
*   **User Action Link**: A "Sign In" link.

**B. Article Content Area**
*   **Article Title**: "A developer's guide to MCP auth."
*   **Article Subtitle/Summary**: "Everything you need to know to secure your MCP server using OAuth 2.1 and PKCE, server and auth metadata, client registration, JWT validation, and role-based access control."
*   **Article Metadata**:
    *   Author identification: "Maria Paletti."
    *   Publication date: "October 7, 2025."
*   **Article Introduction**: Provides an overview of the guide's content and its relevance to securing MCP servers.

**C. In-Article Navigation Section**
*   **Section Title**: "IN THIS ARTICLE."
*   **Internal Navigation List**: A list of clickable links to major headings within the current article, allowing quick navigation to specific topics. The links include:
    *   "Introduction"
    *   "MCP architecture 101"
    *   "The evolution of MCP auth"
    *   "Authentication patterns in MCP"
    *   "The core OAuth flow for MCP"
    *   "Handle public clients with PKCE"
    *   "Protected Resource Metadata: The MCP server's security guide"
    *   "Authorization Server Metadata: The OAuth server's communication manual"
    *   "Dynamic Client Registration: How clients introduce themselves"
    *   "Access Tokens: Validate before use"
    *   "Enforcing access control with RBAC"
    *   "Putting it all together"
    *   "Use WorkOS as your OAuth server for MCP"
    *   "Add roles and permissions with WorkOS RBAC"
    *   "Final thoughts"

**D. Main Article Body**
This section contains the detailed content of the guide, structured with headings, subheadings, explanatory text, diagrams, code examples, and informational callouts.

*   **"MCP architecture 101" Section**: Explains the fundamental components of MCP authentication (host, client, server) and includes a diagram illustrating user and client interaction with host and server components. Defines authentication and authorization. Includes an informational callout linking to internal WorkOS documentation on server components, logic, and architecture.
*   **"The evolution of MCP auth" Section**: Discusses the historical context of MCP authentication and the transition to OAuth 2.1, PKCE, and improved security practices.
*   **"Authentication patterns in MCP" Section**: Describes two approaches:
    *   "1. Service access via API keys": Details characteristics and considerations (unlimited access, rotation requirements, no expiry/traceability).
    *   "2. User or service access via OAuth": Recommends OAuth 2.1 for production scenarios, emphasizing scoped and time-limited tokens.
*   **"The core OAuth flow for MCP" Section**: Describes the typical OAuth 2.1 flow, identifies key actors (MCP client, OAuth server, MCP server), and lists a 6-step process for obtaining an access token.
*   **"Handle public clients with PKCE" Section**: Explains the Authorization Code Flow with PKCE for handling public clients securely, detailing the problem PKCE solves and its implementation.
*   **"Protected Resource Metadata: The MCP server's security guide" Section**: Describes how MCP servers publish machine-readable security configuration via a well-known endpoint, including examples of the endpoint URL and a JSON data structure for protected resource metadata.
*   **"Authorization Server Metadata: The OAuth server's communication manual" Section**: Explains how authorization servers publish their capabilities via a well-known endpoint, with an example of the endpoint URL and a JSON data structure detailing supported scopes, grant types, and endpoints.
*   **"Dynamic Client Registration: How clients introduce themselves" Section**: Discusses how clients can register themselves dynamically with an authorization server, including an example of a POST request JSON payload.
*   **"Access Tokens: Validate before use" Section**: Defines access tokens as bearer tokens and JSON Web Tokens (JWTs), detailing the three parts of a JWT (Header, Payload, Signature) with examples of standard and custom claims. Outlines a 5-step process for validating a JWT, followed by a Python code example demonstrating JWT validation logic. Includes an informational callout suggesting further resources for JWT validation.
*   **"Enforcing access control with RBAC" Section**: Explains the importance of Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) in conjunction with OAuth scopes. Presents a data table showing roles, allowed scopes, and example actions (e.g., 'reader' role allows 'read:data' scope for 'View analytics data').

This is a documentation page from PlanetScale, specifically explaining "Artifact tables in schema changes" within their Vitess product offering. The primary purpose of the page is to provide detailed technical information and guidance regarding the function, naming conventions, cleanup, billing, and storage considerations for artifact tables during database schema changes.

**2. Sections:**

*   **Global Navigation Header:**
    *   Company logo linking to the PlanetScale homepage.

        *   Integrations
        *   Development (with a sub-item: ETL)

*   **Main Content Area (Article: "Artifact tables in schema changes"):**
    *   **Page Title:** "Artifact tables in schema changes".
    *   **Copy Page Button:** Allows users to copy the content of the page.
    *   **Overview Section:** Provides a general introduction to artifact tables in Vitess during online schema changes, including a link to "online schema changes".
    *   **What are artifact tables? Section:** Defines artifact tables, explains their creation by "VReplication", and their role as intermediate storage for non-blocking migrations.
    *   **Naming conventions Section:** Describes the specific naming patterns for artifact tables, presenting a list of prefixes with their purposes and examples:
        *   `_vt_wr_`: For deploy and revert processes.
        *   `_vt_vrp_`: For tables actively used in VReplication during online schema changes.
        *   `_vt_hld_`: For tables held until a specified timestamp.
        *   `_vt_drp_`: For tables marked for dropping at a specified timestamp.
    *   **Automatic cleanup Section:** Details the automatic cleanup process for artifact tables 24 hours after a schema change, allowing for data flushing.
        *   **Exception for foreign key constraints Sub-section:** Explains that databases with foreign key constraints cause immediate dropping of artifact tables, bypassing the 24-hour wait.
    *   **Billing Section:** States that artifact tables do not contribute to storage costs, with a link to "network-attached storage" documentation (mentioning Amazon Elastic Block Storage or Google Persistent Disk).
    *   **Storage considerations Section:**
        *   **Metal instances Sub-section:** Discusses the temporary storage impact on Metal instances and advises ensuring sufficient instance size.
        *   **Storage estimation and protection Sub-section:** Explains PlanetScale's mechanism to prevent storage exhaustion during schema changes by estimating usage (`table_size * 2`) and blocking deploy requests if storage would be exceeded. Details the components of this estimate (copied data, binlogs, operational overhead). Mentions that estimated usage is displayed on the deploy page, and insufficient storage prevents a deploy request, linking to "make a copy of the changed table". Also covers shard-specific estimates for sharded databases.
    *   **Instant deployments exception Sub-section:** Clarifies that instant deployments using `ALGORITHM=INSTANT` do not require artifact table copies.
    *   **Related topics Section:** Presents a collection of links to additional relevant documentation topics:
        *   How online schema change tools work
        *   Deploy requests
        *   VReplication (an external link)
        *   PlanetScale pricing and storage
    *   **Need help? Section:** Provides resources for support, including a link to "the PlanetScale Support team" and a link to a "GitHub discussion board", with additional text regarding how others use PlanetScale.

        *   What are artifact tables?

## Functional Description of Web Console Documentation Page

### 1. Page Overview
This is a documentation page for the PlanetScale "Web console" feature. Its primary purpose is to provide users with comprehensive information and instructions on how to use the web console to run MySQL queries and DDL statements against their PlanetScale database branches.

### 2. Sections

**Global Header Section:**
*   **Product Branding:** Displays the PlanetScale logo, which serves as a link to the main site.
*   **Main Navigation:** A set of links for high-level product areas: Platform, Vitess (currently active), Postgres, API Reference, CLI Reference.
*   **Search Functionality:** An input field with a "Search..." placeholder, indicating it can be used to search the documentation or site content. It includes a keyboard shortcut hint "⌘K".
*   **Assistance Link:** A link labeled "Ask AI" with an accompanying icon, suggesting AI-powered help.
*   **User Account Actions:** Links for "Log in" and "Get started" related to user authentication or initial setup.
*   **Call-to-Action:** A button labeled "Book a meeting".
*   **Interface Theme Toggle:** An icon (sun) representing a control to switch the interface theme.

**Side Navigation Section:**
*   **General Resources:** A list of links for general information: Blog, Contact Us, Status, Benchmarks.
*   **Product Documentation Categories:**
    *   A heading "Vitess" indicating the current documentation product context.
    *   An expandable list of general "Platform" topics, including "Getting Started" which is currently expanded to reveal sub-topics.
    *   A list of specific documentation topics related to Vitess, where "Web console" is highlighted as the currently active page. Other topics include: Vitess architecture, Vitess workflow, Step-by-step guide, Cluster sizing, Cluster configuration, Selecting a region, Replicas, Foreign key constraints support, Terminology, MySQL compatibility, Imports, Connecting, Schema changes, Monitoring, Backups, Scaling, Sharding, Vectors, Metal.

**Main Content Section:**
*   **Page Title:** "Web console".
*   **Introductory Paragraph:** Describes the web console as an interactive interface for running MySQL queries and DDL (Create, Alter, and Delete) against PlanetScale database branches.
*   **"Copy page" Action:** A button labeled "Copy page" with an accompanying dropdown indicator, suggesting additional copy options or formats.
*   **"Get started" Subsection:**
    *   Explains that the web console is used for querying database branches and is by default disabled for production branches.
    *   Provides instructions for accessing the web console, including navigating to a database, clicking the "Console" tab, selecting a branch from a dropdown, and clicking "Connect".
    *   Mentions that queries can be run and DDL applied without `safe migrations` enabled.
    *   Presents a list of useful MySQL statement examples: `SHOW TABLES`, `DESCRIBE table_name`, `EXPLAIN`.
*   **"Supported console commands" Subsection:**
    *   Presents a list of commands with their descriptions.
    *   Includes an interactive command input field labeled "Ask a question..." with an icon for attaching files or content and a button to submit the command.
*   **"Enable for production branches" Subsection:**
    *   Explains the default disablement of the web console for production branches.
    *   Provides steps to enable it: navigating to the database's "Settings" page, selecting a specific checkbox labeled "Allow web console access to production branches", and clicking a "Save database settings" button.
*   **"Need help?" Subsection:**
    *   Offers links to "the PlanetScale Support team" and a "GitHub discussion board" for further assistance.
*   **Page Feedback Section:** A question "Was this page helpful?" with two interactive buttons: "Yes" (with a thumbs-up icon) and "No" (with a thumbs-down icon).
*   **Related Topic Navigation:**
    *   A section providing navigation to the "Previous" documentation topic, "Foreign key constraints".
    *   A section providing navigation to the "Next" documentation topic, "PlanetScale terminology".

**On-page Navigation Section:**
*   **Heading:** "On this page".
*   **Internal Links:** A list of links that navigate to specific subsections within the current page: Get started, Supported console commands, Enable for production branches, Need help?.

**Global Footer Section:**
*   **Social Media Links:** A set of links to various social media platforms, represented by icons: a general "X" link, GitHub, LinkedIn, YouTube, and Facebook.

### 3. Interactive Elements

*   **Navigation Links:** All links in the Global Header, Side Navigation, and On-page Navigation sections are clickable and direct users to different pages or sections.
*   **Search Input:** Allows users to type and search.
*   **"Ask AI" Link:** Initiates an AI assistance interaction.
*   **"Log in" / "Get started" Links:** Lead to authentication or onboarding flows.
*   **"Book a meeting" Button:** Triggers a meeting scheduling process.
*   **Theme Toggle:** Changes the display theme of the interface.
*   **"Copy page" Button with Dropdown:** Copies content, potentially offering different formats via the dropdown.
*   **Hyperlinks within Main Content:** Links such as "disabled for production branches", `app.planetscale.com/<org>/<database>/settings`, "PlanetScale Support team", and "GitHub discussion board" navigate to related information or external resources.
*   **Command Input Field:** An interactive text input labeled "Ask a question..." for entering commands or queries.
*   **Upload/Attach Button:** An icon next to the command input field for attaching files or content.
*   **Submit Button:** A button next to the command input field to send the entered command.
*   **Feedback Buttons:** "Yes" and "No" buttons allow users to provide feedback on the page's helpfulness.
*   **Previous/Next Navigation Links:** Allow users to navigate sequentially through documentation topics.

### 4. Content Details

*   **Main Heading:** "Web console".
*   **Main Description:** "The PlanetScale web console is an interactive interface for running MySQL queries and DDL (Create, Alter, and Delete) against your PlanetScale database branches."
*   **"Get started" Details:**
    *   Mentions web console is "disabled for production branches" by default to prevent accidental data loss.
    *   Highlights the use of `safe migrations` for DDL application.
    *   **MySQL Statement Examples:**
        *   `SHOW TABLES;`: Purpose is "to see a list of the tables in your database branch."
        *   `DESCRIBE table_name;`: Purpose is "to obtain information about a given table's structure."
        *   `EXPLAIN` in front of `SELECT`, `DELETE`, `INSERT`, `REPLACE` and `UPDATES` statements: Purpose is "to learn how the database is executing a query. This can be useful for optimizing slow queries."
*   **"Supported console commands" Details (partial list):**
    *   `?, \?`: "Synonym for help"
    *   `clear, \c`: "Clear the current input statement"
    *   `help, \h`: (Functionality implied by input field: allows asking a question)
    *   `ego, \G`: "Send command to server"
    *   `go, \g`: "Send command to server"
*   **"Enable for production branches" Details:**
    *   Requires navigating to `app.planetscale.com/<org>/<database>/settings`.
    *   Specific checkbox: "Allow web console access to production branches".
    *   Requires clicking "Save database settings" button.
*   **"Need help?" Links:**
    *   "the PlanetScale Support team"
    *   "GitHub discussion board"

1. Page Overview: Documentation page explaining the Model Context Protocol (MCP). The purpose is to educate the reader about MCP, its objectives, importance, concepts, and potential applications.

2. Sections:
    *   Header: Contains site navigation including links to Products, Developers, Resources, and Pricing. Also contains a link to Sign In.
    *   Guides Navigation: A list of links providing navigation within the "Guides" section.
    *   Main Content:
        *   Article Title: "What is the Model Context Protocol (MCP)?"
        *   Introductory Text: Definition of MCP as an open standard that connects AI assistants to systems where data flows.
        *   Key Objectives of MCP: A list describing the objectives, including "Universal access", "Secure, standardized connections", and "Sustainability".
        *   Why is MCP Important?: Explains the importance of MCP, listing benefits such as "More relevant AI", "Unified data access", and "Long-term maintainability".
        *   MCP Core Concepts: Definitions of "Servers", "Clients", and "Tools, resources, prompts" within the MCP framework.
        *   Example: Weather Server in Python: Code example of a weather server in Python.
        *   Emerging Patterns and Future Workflows: Description of how MCP can reshape AI development, including "Agent-led integrations", "On-demand, scoped access", and "Integration-Ready API documentation".
        *   Seamless Collaboration and Knowledge Exchange: Describes how MCP facilitates personal or enterprise knowledge bases.
        *   Standardized Governance and Logging: Explains how MCP can log all AI data access and tool usage.
        *   Speakeasy: A Glimpse of the Future: Describes Speakeasy's approach to generating MCP servers.
        *   Getting Started: Provides links to official Anthropic documentation, MCP quickstarts, Claude Desktop, and Speakeasy.
        *   Final Thoughts: Summary of the benefits of MCP and its implications for the future of AI.
        *   Further Reading: Contains links to other relevant articles.
    *   Footer: Contains links to other company products, resources, and related links.

3. Interactive Elements:
    *   Search Guides: A search input field to find documentation.
    *   Links in Header: Links to "Products", "Developers", "Resources", "Pricing", and "Sign In".
    *   Links in Guides Navigation: Links to navigate to different sections of the guide: "Introduction", "Key Objectives of MCP", "Why is MCP Important?", "MCP core concepts", "Example: weather server in Python", "Emerging patterns and future workflows", "Seamless collaboration and knowledge exchange", "Standardized governance and logging", "Speakeasy: A glimpse of the future", "Getting started", "Final thoughts".
    *   Links in "Further Reading": Links to related articles.

4. Content Details:
    *   Article Title: "What is the Model Context Protocol (MCP)?"
    *   Introductory Text: "Anthropic developed the Model Context Protocol (MCP), an open standard that connects AI assistants to systems where data actually flows—content repositories, business tools, development environments, and more."
    *   Key Objectives of MCP:
        *   "Universal access: Provide a single, open protocol that AI assistants (MCP “clients”) can use to query or retrieve data and context from arbitrary sources."
        *   "Secure, standardized connections: Replace ad hoc API connectors or custom wrappers with a protocol that handles authentication, usage policies, and standardized data formats."
        *   "Sustainability: Foster an ecosystem of reusable connectors (“servers”) so developers can build once and reuse them across multiple LLMs and clients—no more rewriting the same integration in a hundred different ways."
    *   Why is MCP Important?:
        *   "More relevant AI: Even advanced language models are often trained on incomplete or outdated datasets. By connecting them to live data—whether that’s Google Drive documents, official API docs, Slack messages, or an internal database—MCP helps ensure the model’s answers are up-to-date, context-rich, and domain-specific."
        *   "Unified data access: Before MCP, a developer might have to juggle separate plugins, tokens, or custom wrappers to give an LLM system access to multiple sources. With MCP, you configure one protocol, then the LLM can “see” all registered connectors; it’s a step toward a more uniform, standardized ecosystem."
        *   "Long-term maintainability: Ad-hoc solutions become a nightmare as your organization adds more data sources. MCP’s open, standardized approach means less breakage and simpler debugging. Instead of rewriting integrations every time you adopt a new platform, you can rely on (and contribute to) a shared library of MCP servers."
    *   MCP Core Concepts:
        *   "Servers: A server in MCP terms is anything that exposes resources or tools to the model. For example, you might build a server that provides a “get_forecast” function (tool) or a “/policies/leave-policy.md” resource (file-like content)."
        *   "Clients: A client is an LLM-based interface or tool (like Claude for Desktop or a code editor like Cursor) that can discover and invoke MCP servers. This is how the user’s text prompts are turned into actual function calls without constantly switching between systems."
        *   "Tools, resources, prompts:
            *   Tools: Functions the model can call with user approval (e.g., `createJiraTicket`, `updateDatabaseEntry`).
            *   Resources: File-like data the model can read, such as `company_wiki.md` or a dataset representing financial records.
            *   Prompts: Templated text that helps the model perform specialized tasks."
    *   Getting Started:
        *   "Official Anthropic documentation: For a step-by-step introduction, see the official Anthropic documentation."
        *   "MCP quickstarts"
        *   "Open-source connectors: Check out existing servers for Stack, Git, Github, Google Drive, Postgres, and Puppetter."
        *   "Claude Desktop: A convenient way to see MCP in action. Just point your config at a server you built and watch your assistant discover its tools."
        *   "Speakeasy: If you maintain an OpenAPI spec, consider Speakeasy's new MCP server generation. This can help future-proof your API for AI-driven automation."

Includes an information callout stating that invitation emails can be disabled.

It clarifies how users with verified email domains are managed and how directory attributes override other sources. It further explains the management of users with unverified email domains and the process for de-provisioned users, including setting their membership "status" (a link) to "inactive" and subsequent reactivation.

One question addresses reasons why directory users might not be provisioned in AuthKit (missing primary email, unique email requirement). Another question clarifies whether a directory user's email change is reflected in WorkOS (email on the "User object" (a link) is immutable, but the underlying "directory user" (a link) object email is modified).

Lists features such as: RESTful APIs, JSON responses, and standardized objects; Realtime updates from directory services with webhook events; Multiple environments to map to your application development process; Dashboard seamlessly integrates WorkOS into your application; Modern SDKs for Node.js, Ruby, Python, .NET, Go and more; Supports 50+ enterprise services with a single integration point.

*   **Documentation Navigation Sidebar:**
    *   A dropdown selector labeled "Select your SDK" currently displaying "Next.js", allowing users to filter documentation by SDK.
    *   A collapsible "Guides" section containing a list of documentation topics: "Getting started", "Authentication flows", "User management", "Session management", "Organization management", "Billing management", "Account Portal", "Customizing Clerk", and "Securing your app". Each item acts as a link, and some include an indicator for sub-sections.

Each item acts as a link, and some include an indicator for sub-sections.
    *   A "Reference" collapsible section, which is not expanded.

*   **Main Content Area (Image Optimization):**
    *   **Primary Heading:** "Use image optimization to improve app performance".
    *   An introductory paragraph explaining the benefits of image optimization through query parameters for user profile images.
    *   **Secondary Heading:** "Add query parameters to `imageUrl`".
    *   Body text specifying that certain Clerk JavaScript SDK types (User, PublicUserData, Organization) include an `imageUrl` property, and how this URL can be scaled using image optimization options.
    *   A list of image optimization query parameters, each with its name and a functional description:
        *   "`width`": Sets the minimum image width in pixels.
        *   "`height`": Sets the minimum image height in pixels.
        *   "`fit`": Describes how the image should fit its container, listing possible values.
        *   "`scale-down`": Specifies that the image will scale down to fit provided `width` and `height`, but not scale up if smaller.
        *   "`crop`": Specifies that the image will scale down and be cropped to fit the area defined by `width` and `height`.
        *   "`quality`": Specifies image quality for various file types, accepting values from 1 to 100 (defaulting to 85).
    *   **Secondary Heading:** "Example".
    *   Introductory text for the accompanying code example.
    *   A code display area with selectable tabs for "Next.js" (active) and "React", showing an example of implementing image optimization with the specified query parameters. The code includes a file path (`app/image-optimization/page.tsx`).
    *   A button within the code display area to copy the code.

1. Page Overview: Documentation page explaining how to integrate Convex with Clerk.

2. Sections:
    *   Header: Contains the Clerk logo, a search field, an "Ask AI" button and a Sign Up button.
    *   Sidebar Navigation: A list of selectable options, including "Select your SDK", which has options for "Next.js". Contains "Guides" with options for "Reference", "User Management", "Session Management", "Organization Management", "Billing Management", "Account Portal", "Customizing Clerk", "Securing your app", and "Development" (which is expanded to show "Rendering modes", "Verifying OAuth access tokens", "Verifying API keys", "Managing environments", "Clerk environment variables", "Making requests", "Overriding Clerk types/interfaces", "Image optimization", "Shadow/UI CLI", "SIPC", "Model Context Protocol (MCP)", "Webhooks", "Integrations", "Overview", and "Convex").
    *   Main Content Area: Contains the main documentation content.
        *   Title: "Integrate Convex with Clerk"
        *   "Before you start" section with links to "Set up a Clerk application", "Integrate a Clerk SDK into your app", and "Integrate Convex into your app"
        *   "Example repositories" section with links to "Convex's Next.js + Clerk Template" and "Convex's React + Clerk Template"
        *   Introductory text explaining that Convex, with Clerk's authentication and management features, lets users build powerful applications. The text provides a tutorial on how to integrate Clerk into Convex applications.
        *   Numbered steps to guide users through the integration process.
            *   1. Create a JWT template based on Convex. Instructions include navigating to the JWT templates page in the Clerk Dashboard.
            *   2. Instructions to copy and save the issuer URL.
            *   3. Map additional claims, noting that Shortcodes are available to make adding dynamic user values easy.
            *   4. Configure Convex with the Clerk issuer domain. Instructions involve adding the issuer URL to your .env file and creating auth.config.js file.
            *   5. Deploy your changes to Convex using the command "npx convex dev".
            *   6. Configure the Clerk and Convex providers. Contains information about using `<ConvexProviderWithClerk>`, links to "Next.js" and "React", and examples of code for components such as `ConvexClientProvider.tsx` and `app/layout.tsx`.
            *   7. Show UI based on auth state. Explains how to control which UI is shown when the user is signed in or signed out using Convex helper components. Provides code samples.
            *   8. Use auth state in your Convex functions. Describes how to access the information stored in the JWT. Includes a code sample for `convex/messages.ts`.
            *   9. Next steps. Contains a paragraph about Convex's custom hooks, and provides a link to the Convex docs.
    *   Footer: Contains a "Clerk" logo, links to different pages (Product, Developers, Company, Legal), copyright information and social media icons.
